Lessons.title: Greetings
pages:
안녕하세요 [annyeong-haseyo] = Good afternoon./ Hello. / Hi.  / etc...

 안녕 = well-being, health
 하세요 = do you? you do, please do

 When someone greets you with 안녕하세요, you can return the greet with 안녕하세요 too.

 감사합니다 [gam-sa hap-ni-da] = Thank you.

 감사 = thankfulness, gratitude
 합니다 = I do, I am doing 

 You can say thank you to someone with 감사합니다.

Lessons.title: Sorry
pages:
죄송합니다 [joe-song-ham-ni-da] = I am sorry, excuse me

 죄송 = apology, being sorry
 합니다 = I do, I am doing

 To apologize or say I'm sorry, you can use 죄송합니다.

 But if you hear a bad news and want to say sorry to hear that,  you can't use 죄송합니다. It's used to apologize.

저기요 [jeo-gi-yo] = Excuse me

 You can use 저기요 if you want to call waiter in the restaurant.

 You can also use 저기요 if you want to get someone attention.

 If you want to use 'excuse me' to pass through a crowd, you cannot use 저기요.

 You need to use 
 잠시만요 [jam-si-man-yo] = Just a second
 잠깐만요 [jam-kkan-man-yo] = Just a second
 죄송합니다 [joe-song-ham-ni-da]

Lessons.title: Goodbye
pages:
안녕히 계세요 [an-nyeong-hi gye-se-yo]
 Goodbye. Stay in peace, safely.

 안녕히 가세요. [an-nyeong-hi ga-se-yo]
 Goodbye. Go safely.

 Both are said when goodbye, however there's a difference when to use which phrase.

 안녕히 계세요 [an-nyeong-hi gye-se-yo] is used when you are leaving and the other person is staying

 안녕히 가세요. [an-nyeong-hi ga-se-yo] is used when you are staying and the other person is leaving.

Lessons.title: This, that
pages:
이 [i] = this 

 그 [geu] = the, that

 저 [jeo] = the, that ... over there

 이, 그, 저 is used to describe something.
 If it's nearby you use 이 [i].
 If it's further away, you use 그 [geu].
 If it's much further away, you use 저 [jeo]

 For example, 이 사람 [i sa-ram], means this person. 사람 [sa-ram] means person

Lessons.title: Grammar
pages:
이에요 / 예요 [i-e-yo / ye-yo] = to be.

 In English, you build sentence [subject] + [to be] + [object].
 For example: I am Mina.

 But in Korean, your [to be] will be built at the end of the sentence.
 [subject] + [object] + [to be]

 For example: 미나 [Mina] 예요 [to be], which means I'm Mina in English.

Whether to use 이에요 [i-e-yo] or 예요 [ye-yo] is depending on whether the last letter in the previous word ended in a consonant or a vowel.

 Final consonant + 이에요 [i-e-yo]
 No final consonant (Only vowel) + 예요 [ye-yo]

 물이에요 = 물 + 이에요
 [mul + i-e-yo]
 (It’s) water.

 가방이에요 = 가방 + 이에요
 [ga-bang + i-e-yo]
 (It’s) a bag.

학교예요 = 학교 + 예요
 [hak-gyo + ye-yo]
 (It’s) a school.

 저예요 = 저 + 예요
 [jeo + ye-yo]
 (It’s) me

 To ask a question, just change your tone to questioning when speaking

 물이에요. [mul-i-e-yo] = It’s water.
 물이에요? [mul-i-e-yo?] = Is this water?

Lessons.title: This is...
pages:
Previously you learned that 이 = this. To built a sentence, this is a ....we use 이거

 For example:
 이거 책이에요. [i-geo chaek-i-e-yo]
 This is a book. 

 이거 카메라예요. [i-geo ka-me-ra-ye-yo]
 This is a camera.

 이거 커피예요. [i-geo keo-pi-ye-yo]
 This is coffee.

이거 뭐예요? [i-geo mwo-ye-yo?]
 What is this? 

 뭐예요 [mwo-ye-yo?] = What?
 이 = this

 For example:
 이거 뭐예요? [i-geo mwo-ye-yo?]
 What is this?

 이거 물이에요. [i-geo mul-i-e-yo]
 This is water.

 이거 뭐예요? [i-geo mwo-ye-yo?]
 What is this?

 이거 커피예요. [i-geo keo-pi-ye-yo]
 This is coffee.

Lessons.title: Yes / No
pages:
네 [ne] = Yes
 아니요 [a-ni-yo] = No

 For example

 이거 커피예요? [i-geo keo-pi-ye-yo?] =
 Is this coffee?
 네 [ne] = Yes

 이거 커피예요? [i-geo keo-pi-ye-yo?] =
 Is this coffee?
 아니요 [a-ni-yo] = No

Lessons.title: It's not
pages:
아니에요 [a-ni-e-yo] = to be not, it is not
 To say 'something is not', you can use 아니에요 [a-ni-e-yo]

 아니에요 [a-ni-e-yo] is the present tense for the verb 아니다 (to be not).  So 아니에요 [a-ni-e-yo] means 'It’s not.' 'I am not.'

 학생 아니에요
 [hak-saeng a-ni-e-yo]
 not a student

 저 학생 아니에요
 [jeo hak-saeng a-ni-e-yo]
 I am not a student

고양이 아니에요
 [geu-geo go-yang-i a-ni-e-yo]
 not a cat

 이거 고양이 아니에요
 [geu-geo go-yang-i a-ni-e-yo]
 This is not a cat

Lessons.title: Have
pages:
있어요 [i-sseo-yo] = have something 
 없어요 [eop-sseo-yo] = don't have

 있어요 [i-sseo-yo] is the present tense for 있다 [it-da].

 If you use 있어요 on something, it means you have that something.
 If you use 있어요 on a place, it means 'to be there'

 For example:-

 친구 있어요. [chin-gu i-sseo-yo]
 I have friends.

 시간 있어요. [si-gan i-sseo-yo]
 I have time.

 집에 있어요 [jib-e i-sseo-yo.]
 I at home

없어요 [eop-sseo-yo] is the present tense for 없다 [eop-da], which means 'don't have'

 친구 없어요. [chin-gu eop-sseo-yo]
 I don’t have friends

 시간 없어요. [si-gan eop-sseo-yo]
 I don't have time

Simply by changing your tone to questioning tone, the phrase 있어요, 없어요 can be changed into a question

 For example:-
 있어요? [i-sseo-yo]
 Do you have something?

 없어요? [eop-seo-yo]
 Don’t you have ...?

 More example:-

 시간 있어요? [si-gan i-sseo-yo?]
 Do you have some time?

 시간 없어요? [si-gan eop-seo-yo?]
 You don’t have time?

 돈 있어요? [don i-sseo-yo?]
 Do you have money?

 돈 없어요? [don eop-seo-yo?]
 You don’t have money?

Lessons.title: Please give me...
pages:
돈 없어요? [don eop-seo-yo?]
 You don’t have money?

  주세요 [ju-se-yo] = Please give me
 주세요 [ju-se-yo] comes from 주다 [ju-da] which means 'to give'

 [object] + 주세요 [ju-se-yo]
 Please give me [object]

 돈 주세요. [don ju-se-yo]
 Please give me money.

 맥주 주세요. [maek-ju ju-se-yo]
 Please give me a beer

 사과 주세요. [sa-gwa ju-se-yo]
 Please give me (an/some) apple.

김치 주세요. [gim-chi ju-se-yo]
 Please give me some kimchi

  밥 주세요. [bap ju-se-yo]
 Please give me rice.

 물 주세요. [mul ju-se-yo]
 Please give me water

Lessons.title: Delicious
pages:
맛있어요 [ma-si-sseo-yo] = It’s tasty.
 맛 [mat] = taste
 있어요 [i-sseo-yo] = there is
 Putting this together means 맛있어요 [ma-si-sseo-yo] = It’s tasty.

 How about not tasty?
 If 있어요 means there is, 없어요 means there's none.  When combined, it will be 맛없어요 [mad-eop-seo-yo] = It’s not tasty.

 Examples:
 김치 맛있어요[gimchi ma-si-sseo-yo]
 Kimchi is delicious

 저 케익 맛있어요. [jeo ke-ik ma-si-sseo-yo]
 That cake is delicious

 이 차 맛있어요. [i cha ma-si-sseo-yo]
 This tea taste tasty

저 케익 맛없어요.
 [jeo ke-ik ma-deop-seo-yo]
 That cake is not delicous

 이 차 맛없어요.
 [i cha ma-deop-seo-yo]
 This tea taste bad.

 잘 먹겠습니다. [jal meok-ge-sseum-ni-da] = I will eat well.
 In Korea, this phrase is usually said before having a meal. It's also used  especially to someone who is buying the meal.

 When you want to joke that your friend should buy you food, you can say 잘 먹을게! [jal meo-geul-ge!] - informal language
 잘 먹었습니다
 [jal meo-geo-sseum-ni-da]
 Thank someone after meal

Lessons.title: Number
pages:
It's time to learn about number. In Korean, there's 2 type of numbers counting.

 The first type is Sino-Korean, which has influence from China.

 일 [il] = 1
 이 [i] = 2
 삼 [sam] = 3
 사 [sa] = 4
 오 [o] = 5
 육 [yuk] = 6
 칠 [chil] = 7
 팔 [pal] = 8
 구 [gu] = 9
 십 [sip] = 10
If you want to say 12, you just say [TEN] + [TWO] = 십이

 If you want to say 45, you just say [FOUR] + [TEN] + [FIVE] = 사십오

 십 [sip] = 10
 십 [sip] + 일 = 11
 십 [sip] + 이 = 12
 ......
 이십 [i-sip] = 20
 이십일 [i-sip-il] = 21
 이십이 [i-sip-i] = 22
 ......
 백 [baek] = 100
 백일 [baek-il] = 101
 ......
삼백일 [sam-baek-il] = 301
 ......
 천 [cheon] = 1000
 천구십팔 [cheon-gu-sip-pal]= 1098

 Please note that there's no need to say 일 [il] for 100, 1000 or 10000.

 백 [baek] = 100, and not 일백 [il-baek]
 천 [cheon] = 1000, and not 일천 [il-cheon]
 만 [man] = 10000, and not 일만 [il-man]

Lessons.title: Number II
pages:
The second type of number is called Native Korean Number.

 하나 [ha-na]  = 1
 둘 [dul] = 2
 셋 [set] = 3
 넷 [net] = 4
 다섯 [da-seot] = 5
 여섯 [yeo-seot] = 6
 일곱 [il-gop] = 7
 여덟 [yeo-deol] = 8
 아홉 [a-hop] = 9
 열 [yeol] = 10

From 11 to 19, it's [Ten] + [number 1-9]..
 열하나 [yeol-ha-na]  = 11
 열둘 [yeol-dul] = 12
 열셋 [yeol-set] = 13
 열넷 [yeol-net] = 14

 Same rules apply for 21-29,
 but for 20 it's 스물 [seu-mul]
 스물 [seu-mul] = 20
 스물둘 [seu-mul-dul] = 22
 스물셋 [seu-mul-set] = 23

 The same applies for 30-99
 서른 [seo-reun] = 30
 마흔 [ma-heun] = 40
 쉰 [swin] = 50
 예순 [ye-sun] = 60
 일흔 [i-reun] = 70
 여든 [yeo-deun] = 80
 아흔 [a-heun] = 90

How about 100, 1000 and above?
 For bigger numbers, native Korean numbers are not used anymore. We use sino-Korean number again.

 백 [baek / 100] (sino-Korean) + 하나 [ha-na / 1] (native Korean) = 101 = 백하나

 사 [sa / 4] (sino-Korean) + 백 [baek / 100] (sino-Korean) + 다섯 [daseot / 5] (native Korean) = 405 = 사백다섯

 So when do we use which type of numbers? There's a many situations to use which type and it's  difficult to explain this within today lesson. For example:-

 For time, we use native Korean to say the hour and sino-Korean to say the minutes.
 For age - 살 [sal]. we use native-Korean.

Lessons.title: Age
pages:
After learning sino-Korean number and native-Korean number,  it's time to put this to use.  살 [sal] = age

 To say 12 years old, we say
 열두 살 [yeol-dul-sal] = 12 years old

 To say this in a sentence, we add 이에요 [i-e-yo] at the end of the sentence.

 한 살이에요 [han-sal i-e-yo]
 I am 1 years old.

 열두 살이에요 [yeol-dul-sal i-e-yo]
 I am 12 years old.

 마흔네 살이에요 [ma-heun-ne-sal i-e-yo]
 I am 44 years old.

스물 살이에요
 [seu-mul-sal i-e-yo]
 I am 20 years old.

 스물네 살이에요
 [seu-mul-ne-sal i-e-yo]
 I am 24 years old.

 여든 살이에요
 [yeo-deun-sal i-e-yo]
 I am 80 years old.

Lessons.title: Counter
pages:
More lesson on counting today.
 개 [gae] = general use to count thing, but can't be used on all objects.
 명 [myeong] = counter for people
 마리 [ma-ri] = counter animals
 대 [dae] = counter for cars
 장 [jang] = counter for papers

 Examples:-
 한 명 [han myeong]
 1 person

 친구 두 명 [chin-gu du myeong]
 2 friends

 사과 다섯 개 [sa-gwa da-seot gae]
 5 apples

고양이 두 마리 [goyang-i du mari]
 2 cats

 차 세 대 [cha se dae]
 3 cars.

Lessons.title: I want to ...
pages:
[verb] + 고 싶어요 [-go si-peo-yo] = I want to ...

 The above is used to mention I want to do ________.

 For example:- 
 보다 [bo-da] = to see
 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat
 사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 마시다 [ma-si-da] = to drink

 Drop the 다 and + 고 싶어요 you will have 
 보고 싶어요 [bo-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to watch or I miss you

 먹고 싶어요 [meok-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to eat

김치 먹고 싶어요
 [gim-chi meok-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to eat kimchi

 영화 보고 싶어요
 [yeong-hwa bo-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to watch movie

 바나나 사고 싶어요
 [ba-na-na sa-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to buy banana

 물 마시고 싶어요
 [mul ma-si-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to drink water.

Lessons.title: What you want to ....?
pages:
뭐 하고 싶어요? [mwo ha-go si-peo-yo?] = What do you want to do? 

 Previously we learned how to say, we want to _____. Today we will learn how to ask the question. What do you want to do?

 뭐 [mwo] = what
 싶어요 [si-peo-yo] = want to

 When combined you get
 뭐 하고 싶어요? [mwo ha-go si-peo-yo?]
 What do you want to do?

Remember previously we learned that to use verb 하다, 보다, etc, we removed 다 from the sentence.

 Let's change 하다 [ha-da] to another verb

 뭐 보고 싶어요? [mwo bo-go si-peo-yo?]
 What you want to watch?

 뭐 먹고 싶어요? [mwo meok-go si-peo-yo?]
 What you want to eat?

 뭐 읽고 싶어요? [mwo il-ggo si-peo-yo]?
 What you want to read?

 뭐 놀고 싶어요? [mwo nol-go si-peo-yo]
 What you want to play?

Lessons.title: Grammar (Present tense)
pages:
It's time to learn about Korean tenses. Just like English, Korean has Present, Past and Future tense. Today we will have a look on present tense.

 If you look at Korean dictionary, all verbs ends with 다.
 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 자다 [ja-da] = to sleep
 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat

 To form this verb into a sentence, you will need to drop 다. Then, you joined with one of these:-
 아요 [a-yo]
 어요 [eo-yo]
 여요 [yeo-yo]

If the verb end with ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o], we joined with 아요 [a-yo].

 If the verb is NOT end with ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o], we joined with 어요 [eo-yo].

 If verb is 하 [ha], we joined with 여요 [yeo-yo].

가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가 last vowel is ㅏ [a] so you add 아요 [a-yo]
 가 + 아요 = 가요 [ga-yo]

 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat
 먹 last vowel is ㅓ [eo], so you add 어요 [eo-yo]
 먹 + 어요 = 먹어요 [meo-geo-yo]

 보다 [bo-da] = to watch
 보 last vowel is ㅗ [o], so you add 아요 [a-yo]
 보 + 아요 = 봐요 [bwa-yo]

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 If ends with 하, we add 여요. 하 + 여요 = 하여요 [ha-yeo-yo] and it becomes 해요 [hae-yo].

Lessons.title: Grammar (Past tense)
pages:
Today we will learn past tense. It's the same concept as present tense.

 To form verb into a sentence, you joined with one of these:-
 았어요 [a-sseo-yo]
 었어요 [eo-sseo-yo]
 였어요 [yeo-sseo-yo]

 If the verb (after dropping 다) last vowel is ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o], it is followed by 았어요 [a-sseo-yo].

 If the last vowel is NOT ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o], it is followed by 었어요 [eo-sseo-yo].

 If it's end with 하 [ha], is followed by 였어요 [yeo-sse-yo].
 Similar like the present tense right?

가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가 last vowel is ㅏ [a] so you add 았어요 [a-sseo-yo]
 가 + 았어요 = 갔어요 [ga-a-sseo-yo]

 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat
 먹 last vowel is ㅓ [eo], so you add 었어요 [eo-sseo-yo]
 먹 + 었어요 = 먹었어요 [meo-geo-sseo-yo]

 보다 [bo-da] = to watch
 보 last vowel is ㅗ [o], so you add 았어요 [a-sseo-yo]
 보 + 았어요 = 봤어요

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 If ends with 하, we add 였어요
 하 + 였어요 = 했어요 [hae-sseo-yo].

Lessons.title: When?
pages:
Previously you have learn how to ask what? 뭐 [mwo]

 Today you will learn to ask when?
 언제 [eon-je] = When

 Just add 언제 [eon-je] right in front of your question. For example:-
 When did you did it?
 언제 했어요? [eon-je hae-sseo-yo?]
 When + you did it?

 When did you came?
 언제 왔어요? [eon-je wa-sseo-yo?]
 When + did you came?

 When do you wake up?
 언제 일어나요? [eon-je i-reo-na-yo?]
 When + do you wake up?

You will need to learn some vocabulary to reply someone who ask you when did you ______?.

 오늘 [o-neul] = today
 내일 [nae-il] = tomorrow
 어제 [eo-je] = yesterday
 지금 [ji-geum] = now
 나중에 [na-jung-e] = later
 아까 [a-kka] = a while ago today

Lessons.title: Where?
pages:
Where? 어디 [eo-di] = where
 Just like what, when, we put where 어디 at the start of the sentence.

 어디 가요? [eo-di ga-yo?]
 Where do you go?

 While the above is correct, to make your message is clear, we normally use 에 [e] and 에서 [e-seo]  to mark location. 

So for better way of communicating, we use
 어디에 가요? [eo-di-e ga-yo?]
 Where do you go?

Another example
 어디에 있어요? [eo-di-e i-sseo-yo?]
 Where are you?

 에서 [e-seo] is used to
 1. mark a location where action taking place
 or
 2. from somewhere (from Korea)

 집에서 먹어요 [jib-e-so meog-eoyo]
 I eating at home
 집에 있어요 [jib-e i-sseo-yo]
 I at home.

 Do you see the difference?

Lessons.title: Grammar (Marker)
pages:
Subject and Topic marker
 In building sentences in Korean, subject and topic marker can emphasize what you talking about.

 은 [eun] / 는 [neun]

 Above is used to mark a topic. Topic markers are to let people know what topic you are talking about and it's attached to noun.

 We use these topic markers with the rules below:-
 Word ending with a last consonant + -은
 Word ending with a vowel + -는
For example:-
 저는 학생이에요
 [jeo-neun hak-saeng-i-e-yo]
 I am a student.

 오늘은 일해요
 [o-neul-eun il-hae-yo]
 Today I am working

 Besides marking topics, 은 [eun] / 는 [neun] is used to emphasize of about something

 오늘 날씨 좋네요
 [o-neul nal-ssi jot-ne-yo]
 The weather is good today.

 오늘은 날씨 좋네요
 [o-neul-eun nal-ssi jot-ne-yo]
 (The weather is not good recently) But today it is good

오늘 날씨는 좋네요
 [o-neul nal-ssi-neun jot-ne-yo]
 (Today other things is not so good) But the weather  is good.

 오늘 [o-neul] = today
 날씨 [nal-ssi] = weather
 좋네요 [jot-ne-yo] = good

Subject marking particles are
 이 [i] / 가 [ga] 

 Words ending with a last consonant + 이
 Words ending with a vowel + 가
 Subject marking particles (이/가) show what the subject of the sentence is.

 뭐가 좋아요? [mwo-ga jo-a-yo?]
 What is good?

 Generally, 은/는 is not so commonly used all over sentences.  Usually, 은/는/이/가 can be dropped, but when you need particles to clarify the  meaning, 이/가 will be more commonly used.

Lessons.title: Negative
pages:
In this lesson, we will learn how to build negative sentence.

 There's 2 ways to do it
 1. Add 안 [an] before a verb
 2. Use 지 않다 [ji an-da]

 먹어요 [meo-geo-yo] = eating
 안 먹어요 [an-meo-geo-yo] not eating

 매워요 [mae-wo-yo] = spicy
 안 매워요 [an mae-wo-yo] = not spicy

 가요 [ga-yo] = go
 안 가요 [an ga-yo] = don't go

 Easy right?

Using method 2, 지 않다 is more complicated as you need to take care of the tense.

 가요 [ga-yo] = go
 가지 않아요 [ga-ji a-na-yo] = don't go
 가지 않았어요 [ga-ji a-na-sseo-yo] = didn't go.

Lessons.title: Who
pages:
누구 [nu-gu] = who

 누구예요? [nu-gu-ye-yo?] = Who is it?

 Lets try use subject particle 이 [i] / 가 [ga] on the question above.

 누구 (who) + 가 (subject marker) = 누가

 누가 젠이에요? [nu-ga jen-i-e-yo?]
 Who is Jen (among a bunch of people)?

 누가 했어요? [nu-ga hae-sseo-yo?]
 Who did it?

Lessons.title: Why
pages:
왜 [wae] = Why

 Again just like what, when, who, we use 왜 [wae] at the start of the sentence.

 왜 안 전화했어요?
 [wae jeon-hwa-hae-sseo-yo?]
 Why didn't you call?

 왜 왔어요? [wae wa-sseo-yo?]
 Why you came?

 왜 했어요? [wae hae-sseo-yo?]
 Why you did it?

Lessons.title: How
pages:
어떻게 [eo-tteo-ke] = How
 어떻게 왔어요? [eo-tteo-ke wa-sseo-yo?]
 How did you get here?
 어떻게 가요? [eo-tteo-ke ga-yo?]
 How do you go?

 얼마 [eol-ma] = How much
 얼마예요? [eol-ma-ye-yo?]
 How much is it?
 얼마 냈어요? [eol-ma nae-sseo-yo?]
 How much you paid?
 내다 = to pay

 얼마나 + adjective/adverb = how  _____
 얼마나 커요? [eol-ma-na keo-yo?]
 How big is it?
 커 [keo] = big

 얼마나 매워요? [eol-ma-na mae-wo-yo?]
 How spicy is it?
 매워요 [mae-wo-yo] = spicy

Lessons.title: From A to B
pages:
How to say from A to B?

 에서 [e-seo] or 부터 [bu-teo] = from 
 까지 [kka-ji] = to

 We can use this for location, for example
 서울 [seo-ul] = Seoul
 서울에서 [seo-ul-e-seo] = from Seoul

 제주 [je-ju] = Jeju
 제주까지 [je-ju kka-ji] = to Jeju

 서울에서 제주까지
 [seo-ul-e-seo je-ju kka-ji]
 from Seoul to Jeju

 여기에서 저기까지
 [yeo-gie-seo jeo-gi-kka-ji]
 from here to there

You can also use to describe time.
 지금부터 [ji-geum-bu-teo] = from now
 내일까지 [nae-il-kka-ji] = until tomorrow

 지금부터 내일까지
 [ji-geum-bu-teo nae-il-kka-ji]
 from now until tomorrow

 Depending on cases, either 에서 [e-seo] or 부터 [bu-teo] can be used to describe from Seoul to Jeju.  But you can't use 에서 to describe 'from now (time)'. You can only use 부터

 Another example
 어제부터 [eo-je-bu-teo] = from yesterday
 내일까지 [nae-il-kka-ji] = until tomorrow
 어제부터 내일까지
 [eo-je-bu-teo nae-il-kka-ji]
 from yesterday until tomorrow

Lessons.title: Days in a week
pages:
Days of the week

 월요일 [wo-ryo-il] = Monday
 화요일 [hwa-yo-il] = Tuesday
 수요일 [su-yo-il] = Wednesday
 목요일 [mo-gyo-il] = Thursday
 금요일 [geu-myo-il] = Friday
 토요일 [to-yo-il] = Saturday
 일요일 [i-ryo-il] = Sunday

 요일 means 'day of the week'

If 월, 화, 수, 목, 금, 토, 일 used alone, it means
 월 [wol] = moon
 화 [hwa] = fire
 수 [su] = water
 목 [mok] = wood
 금 [geum] = gold
 토 [to] = soil, earth
 일 [il] = sun

 For examples:-
 저는 금요일에 영화를 봤어요.
 [jeo-neun geu-myo-i-re yeong-hwa-reul bwa-sseo-yo]
 I watched movie on Friday.

 어제는 재미는 일요일이었어요.
 [eo-je-neun jae-mi-neun i-ryo-il-i-eo-sseo-yo]
 Yesterday is a fun Sunday.

Lessons.title: Planets
pages:
Planets

 Remember days of the week in previous lesson?  You can take the same words for planets.

 화성 [hwa-seong] = Mars
 수성 [su-seong] = Mercury
 목성 [mok-seong] = Jupiter
 금성 [geum-seong] = Venus
 토성 [to-seong] = Saturn

Lessons.title: And
pages:
하고 [ha-go] = and.

 We use 하고 to connect sentence, which means 'and'. For example, 

 이거하고 저거 [i-geo-ha-go jeo-geo] = this and that

 이거 [i-geo] = this
 저거 [jeo-geo] = that
 하고 [ha-go] = and

(이)랑 [(i)rang] = and / with

 You can also (이)랑 [(i)rang] to mean 'and'. If noun ends with vowel, you use 랑 and if it ends with a final consonant, you use 이랑

 For example:-
 사과랑 빵 샀어요
 [sa-gwa-rang ppang sa-sseo-yo] = 
 I bought apple and bread

 빵 [ppang] = bread
 사과 [sa-gwa] = apple
 샀어요 [sa-sseo-yo] = bought

Besides meaning 'and', both 하고 and (이)랑 can also mean 'with', depending on the context.

 For example:-
 친구하고 영화 봤어요.
 [chin-gu-ha-go yeong-hwa bwa-sseo-yo] =
 I watched movie with a friend.

 In this context, it is impossible to mean 'I watch friend and movie' right?

 누구랑 갔어요?
 [nu-gu-rang ga-sseo-yo?] =
 Who did you went with?

More examples:-
 1. 여자친구하고 데이트 갔어요.
 [yeo-ja-chin-gu-ha-go de-i-teu gass-eo-yo]
 I went to a date with my girlfriend

 여자친구 [yeo-ja-chin-gu] = girlfriend
 데이트 [de-i-teu] = date
 갔어요 [gass-eo-yo] = went

 2. 친구하고 밥을 먹었어요
 [chin-gu-ha-go ba-beul meog-eoss-eoyo]
 I ate with friends

 친구 [chin-gu] = friend
 밥 [bab] = rice
 먹었어요 [meog-eoss-eoyo] = ate

Lessons.title: And then, therefore
pages:
그리고 [geu-ri-go] = and / and then.

 그리고 [geu-ri-go] can mean of 'and' or 'and then', depending on the context.

 For example:-
 빵, 커피, 그리고 우유 [ppang, keo-pi, geu-ri-go u-yu] = bread, coffee, and milk

친구를 만났어요. 그리고 밥을 먹었어요.
 [chin-gu-reul man-na-sseo-yo. geu-ri-go ba-beul meo-geo-sseo-yo]
 I met friend. And then, we ate rice (having a meal).

 친구를 만났어요.
 [chin-gu-reul man-na-sseo-yo.] =
 I met friend.

 밥을 먹었어요.
 [ba-beul meo-geo-sseo-yo.] =
 Ate rice / meal.

그래서 [geu-rae-seo] = therefore

 오늘은 비가 왔어요.
 [o-neul-eun bi-ga wa-sseo-yo] =
 Today rained.

 집에 있었어요.
 [ji-be i-sseo-sseo-yo] =
 I at home.

 오늘은 비가 왔어요. 그래서 집에 있었어요
 [o-neul-eun bi-ga wa-sseo-yo. geu-rae-seo i-be i-sseo-sseo-yo]
 Today rained. Therefore, I was at home.

김치는 맛있어요.
 [gim-chi-neun ma-si-sseo-yo.] =
 Kimchi is delicious.

 김치를 많이 먹어요.
 [gim-chi-reul ma-ni meo-geo-yo.] =
 I eat alot kimchi.

 김치는 맛있어요. 그래서 김치를 많이 먹어요.
 [gim-chi-neun ma-si-sseo-yo. geu-rae-seo gim-chi-reul ma-ni meo-geo-yo] =
 Kimchi is delicious. Therefore, I eat alot.

Lessons.title: But, however
pages:
그렇지만 [geu-reo-chi-man] = but.
 그런데 [geu-reon-de] = but.

 You can use 그렇지만, 그런데 to mean 'but / however'. For example:-

 피곤해요. 그렇지만 영화 보고 싶어요.
  [pi-gon-hae-yo. geu-reo-chi-man yeong-hwa bo-go si-peo-yo.] =
  I'm tired. But I want to watch movie.

 피곤해요
 [pi-gon-hae-yo] =
 I'm tired.

 영화 보고 싶어요
 [yeong-hwa bo-go si-peo-yo] =
 I want to watch movie.
You can also build the sentence with 그런데 which brings the same meaning.

 피곤해요. 그런데 영화 보고 싶어요.
 [pi-gon-hae-yo. geu-reon-de yeong-hwa bo-go si-peo-yo]

 However, there's a difference between 그렇지만 and 그런데. 그렇지만 is used when 2 sentences  has contrasting meaning. 그런데 can mean 'but' but also is used to imply a meaning 'and'. For example:- 

1. 어제 이거 샀어요. 그런데 정말 작아요.
 [eo-je i-geo sa-sseo-yo. geu-reon-de jeong-mal jag-a-yo.]
 I bought this yesterday. But it's really small. (And I found out it's small)

 2. 어제 이거 샀어요. 그렇지만 정말 작아요.
 [eo-je i-geo sa-sseo-yo. geu-reo-chi-man jeong-mal jag-a-yo.]
 I bought this yesterday. But it's really small. (I'm really disappointed it's small)

 어제 [eo-je] = yesterday
 이거 [i-geo] = this
 샀어요 [sa-sseo-yo] = bought
 정말 [jeong-mal] = really
 작아요 [jag-a-yo] = small

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: You have learned alot and it's time for revision!

Lessons.title: Time
pages:
Let's learn to tell time.
 From our 1st Month study, you should know Korean-Sino and Korean-Native numbers by now. Here's  revision for you.

 Korean-Sino
 일 [il] = 1
 이 [i] = 2
 삼 [sam] = 3
 사 [sa] = 4
 오 [o] = 5
 육 [yuk] = 6
 칠 [chil] = 7
 팔 [pal] = 8
 구 [gu] = 9
 십 [sip] = 10
Korean-Native
 하나 [ha-na] = 1
 둘 [dul] = 2
 셋 [set] = 3
 넷 [net] = 4
 다섯 [da-seot] = 5
 여섯 [yeo-seot] = 6
 일곱 [il-gop]  = 7
 여덟 [yeo-deol] = 8
 아홉 [a-hop] = 9
 열 = 10
To tell the hour, we use Korean Native number + 시 [si].
 To tell the minute, we use Korean-Sino number + 분 [bun].

 For example:-
 다섯 시 [da-seot si] = 5 o’clock 
 열한 시 [yeol-han si] = 11 o’clock
 아홉 시 [a-hop si] = 9 o’clock
 열 시 삼십 분 [yeol si sam-sip bun] = 10.30 am/pm
 두 시 이십 분 [du si i-sip bun] = 2.20 am/pm
 세 시 십오 분 [se si si-bo bun] = 3.15 am/pm
 ** For 1,2,3,4....11,12... o'clock, we use
 한 시 [han si] = 1 o’clock (instead of 하나 시)
 두 시 [du si] = 2 o’clock (instead of 둘 시)
 세 시 [se si] = 3 o’clock (instead of 셋 시)
 네 시 [ne si] = 4 o’clock (instead of 넷 시)
 열한 시 [yeol-han si] = 11 o’clock (instead of 넷 시)

Lessons.title: Time (Part II)
pages:
지금 몇 시예요? [ji-geum myeot si-ye-yo?]
 What is the time now?

 More Example:-
 내일 수업이 몇 시에 끝나요?
 [nae-il su-eo-bi myeot si-e kkeut-na-yo?]
 What time your class finish tomorrow?

 내일 수업이 아홉시 반에 끝나요.
 [nae-il su-eo-bi a-hop-si ba-ne kkeut-na-yo]
 My class finish at 9.30 tomorrow.

 수업 [su-eop] = class
 내일 [nae-il] = tomorrow
 끝나다 [kkeut-na-da] = to finish

오늘 몇 시에 친구를 만나요?
 [o-neul myeot si-e chin-gu-reul man-na-yo?]
 What time you will meet your friend today?

 열 시에 친구를 만나요.
 [yeol si-e chin-gu-reul man-na-yo]
 I meet friend at 10 o'clock.

Lessons.title: To / From someone
pages:
한테서 [han-te-seo] = from someone
 한테 [han-te] = from/by/to/ someone (depending on context)

 As you can see 한테 can mean 'from' or 'to' depending on context. Let's see example for easier understanding.

 너한테 할 말이 있어.
 [neo-han-te hal ma-ri i-sseo.]
 I have something to say to you.

 여자친구한테 차였어요
 [yeo-ja-chin-gu-han-te cha-yeo-sseo-yo]
 I was dumped by my girlfriend
 차이다 [cha-i-da] = to be dumped
여자친구한테서 받은 거예요.
 [yeo-ja-chin-gu-han-te-seo ba-deun geo-ye-yo]
 I received from my girlfriend.
 받다 [bat-da] = to receive

Lessons.title: Only
pages:
만 [man] = Only
 Today lesson is fairly easy. If we want to say 'only', we use 만. For example:-

 이것만 [i-geot-man] = only this
 우유만 [u-yu-man] = only milk

 The above can be done if we combined 만 into noun. If we are to combine into verb, we need to  add -기만 하다 [gi-man ha-da]. 하다 will need to be converted into relevant tense. For example:-

 보다 [bo-da] = to see
 보기만 하다 [bo-gi-man ha-da] = to only see

 놀다 [nol-da] = to play
 놀기만 하다 [nol-gi-man ha-da] = to only play

Let's try build sentence with this.
 우유만 주문했어요.
 [u-yu-man ju-mun-hae-sseo-yo]
 I only ordered milk.

 오늘은 이것만 샀어요
 [o-neul-eun i-geot-man sa-sseo-yo] 
 Today, I only bought this.
 사다 [sa-da] = buy

 어제 놀기만 했어요
 [eo-je nol-gi-man hae-sseo-yo] 
 Yesterday, I only played.
 어제 [eo-je] = yesterday

 학교에서 듣기만 했어요.
 [hag-gyo-e-seo deut-gi-man hae-sseo-yo]
 I only listened at school.
 학교 [hag-gyo]= school
 듣다 [deut-da] = to listen

Lessons.title: A little, very
pages:
조금 [jo-geum] = a little
 아주 [a-ju] = very
 We can use 조금, 아주 to describe 'quantity'

 조금 비싸요. [jo-geum bi-ssa-yo]
 It's a little expensive.

 조금 주세요. [jo-geum ju-se-yo]
 Please give me a little.

 아주 똑똑해요. [a-ju ddok-ddok-hae-yo.]
 Very smart.

 아주 커요. [a-ju keo-yo.]
 Very big.

 아주 예뻐요 [a-ju yep-peo-yo.]
 Very pretty.

Lessons.title: Really, not really, not at all
pages:
정말 [jeong-mal] = really
 정말 비싸요.
 [jeong-mal bi-ssa-yo].
 It's really expensive.

 정말 재미있어요.
 [jeong-mal jae-mi-iss-eo-yo].
 It's really interesting.

 별로 [byeol-lo] = not really
 별로 is only used in negative sentence. Which means, those sentences with 안 or 없어요. For example:-

 별로 안 빨라요.
 [byeol-lo an ppal-la-yo]
 It not really fast.
 ** Check out Month 4 Lesson 25 to understand why 빠르 + 아요 = 빨라요 and not  어요 since it's NOT end with ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o]

별로 안 이상해요.
 [byeol-lo an i-sang-hae-yo]
 It's not really strange.

 전혀 [jeon-hyeo] = not at all

 전혀 means 'not at all'. For example:-

 전혀 안 이상해요.
 [jeon-hyeo an i-sang-hae-yo]
 It's not strange at all.

 전혀 안 빨라요.
 [jeon-hyeo an ppal-la-yo]
 It's not fast at all.

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's revision day again!

Lessons.title: Grammar (Future tense)
pages:
It's time to learn grammar again. In previous month, you have learned past and present tense. Today you will learn about future tense!

 To create future tense (will be ..), you add ㄹ/을 거예요 [l/eul geo-ye-yo] to the verb

 Verb + ㄹ/을 거예요

 As you have guessed,
 verb ending with vowel, we add ㄹ 거예요
 verb ending with consonant, we add 을 거예요
 If verb ending with ㄹ, we just add 거예요
Let's see example now

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 갈 거예요. [gal geo-ye-yo] = will go

 보다 [bo-da]= to watch
 볼 거예요 [bol geo-ye-yo]= will watch

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 할 거예요 [hal geo-ye-yo] = will do

 먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹을 거예요 [meog-eul geo-ye-yo] = will eat

 팔다 [pal-da] = to sell
 팔 거예요 [pal geo-ye-yo] = will sell

Lessons.title: Grammar (Object marker)
pages:
In previous month, you learned about subject marker. Today we will learn about object marker.

 If noun end with vowel, we use 를 [reul]
 If noun end with consonant, we use 을 [eul]

 Example:-
 영화(를) [yeong-hwa-reul] = movie
 텔레비전(을) [tel-le-bi-jeon-eul] = television

So when do we use object marker? Usually we use it when the object is too far from the verb in the sentence.

 영화 봐요 = I watch movie.
 영화를 일주일에 몇 번 봐요? = How many times a week do you watch movie?

 As you can see the 영화 is far away from the verb 봐요. To make the sentence clear, we will use 를

 영화를 봐요 is fine too but it's unnatural when we speak. So if the verb is near the object, we will drop the marker 를.

Lessons.title: Date
pages:
We use Sino-Korean numbers to talk about month.

 1월 / 일월 [i-rwol] = January
 2월 / 이월 [i-wol] = February
 3월 / 삼월 [sa-mwol] = March
 4월 / 사월 [sa-wol] = April
 5월 / 오월 [o-wol] = May
 6월 / 유월 [yu-wol] = June (it's 유, not 육)
 7월 / 칠월 [chi-rwol] = July
 8월 / 팔월 [pa-rwol] = August
 9월 / 구월 [gu-wol] = September
 10월 / 시월 [si-wol] = October (it's 시, not 십)
 11월 / 십일월 [si-bi-rwol] = November
 12월 / 십이월 [si-bi-wol] = December

Same style is used to describe day. Sino-Korean number + 일
 1일 (일일) = 1
 2일 (이일) = 2
 3일 (삼일) = 3
 4일 (사일) = 4

 Please note, in written form you can either write in hangul 사일 or number 4일.

 오늘 몇 월 며칠이에요?
 [o-neul myeo-dwol myeo-chil-i-e-yo?]
 What date is it today?

 십일월십이일
 November 12

Lessons.title: Can / Cannot
pages:
We add -(으)ㄹ 수 있다 [-(eu)l su it-da] to the verb to mean 'can'. For example

 보다 = to see
 볼 수 있다 [bol su it-da] = can see
 먹다 = to eat
 먹을 수 있다 [meo-geul su it-da] = can eat

 By now you should have an idea when to use (으) or ㄹ.
 Verb ending with vowel, we add -ㄹ
 Verb ending with consonant, we add -을

 수 [su] in this context means, have an idea of solving something.
 So, -(으)ㄹ 수 있다 means 'can'
To say cannot, we use (으)ㄹ 수 없다. Easy right?
 볼 수 없다 = cannot see
 먹을 수 없다 = cannot eat

 Lets build some sentences.

 한국어 할 수 있어요?
 [han-gug-eo hal su i-sseo-yo?]
 Can you speak Korean?
 한국어 [han-gug-eo]= Korean language

 지금 만날수있어요?.
 [ji-geum man-nal su i-sseo-yo.]
 Can we meet now?

한국어 할 수 없어요
 I can't speak Korean.

 Another more common way to say 'cannot' is to use 못 [mot].

 지금 못 만나요.
 [ji-geum mot man-na-yo.]
 I cannot meet you now.

 한국어 못 해요.
 [han-gug-eo mot-hae-yo]
 I can't speak Korean.

Lessons.title: Good / Bad at ...
pages:
Good at ....~을/를 잘 하다
 Bad at ...~을/를 못 하다

 요리 [yo-ri] = cooking
 요리를 잘 하다 [yo-ri-reul jal ha-da]
 good at cooking

 수영 [su-yeong] = swimming
 수영을 잘 하다 [su-yeong-eul jal ha-da]
 good at swimming

By changing 잘 to 못 , you can mean bad or unable to do something.

 요리를 못 하다 [yo-ri-reul mot ha-da]
 poor at cooking / cannot cook

 수영을 못 하다 [su-yeong-eul mot ha-da]
 poor at swimming / unable swim

 If you want to only mean poor at..., we use 잘 못. For example:-

 수영을 잘 못 하다
 [su-yeong-eul jal mot ha-da]
 poor at swimming

You can also change 하다 to other verb. For example:- 

 매운 거 잘 못 먹어요
 [mae-un geo jal mot meo-geo-yo]
 Not good at eating spicy food

 저는 글을 잘 써요.
 [jeo-neun geu-reul jal sseo-yo.]
 I'm good at writing.

 쓰다 [sseu-da] = write

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Revision time again!

Lessons.title: Should / Have to
pages:
Have to / should
 To say 'have to / should' we use...
 verb + -아/어/여 + 야 되다/하다

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가야 되다 (가 + 아 = 가) = should go

 쓰다 [sseu-da] = to write
 써야 되다 (쓰 + 어 = 써)= should write

 When to use -아/어/여?
 By now, you should have a good grasp on on these.
 If verb ending in vowels 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ', we joined 아.
 If verb ending in other vowels, we joined with 어.
 If 하, we joined with 여.

자야 돼요
 [ja-ya dwae-yo]
 Should sleep

 해야 돼요
 [hae-ya dwae-yo]
 Should do

 있어야 돼요
 [i-sseo-ya dwae-yo]
 Should be here

 사야 돼요
 [sa-ya dwae-yo]
 Should buy

 You can replace 돼요 with 하요 too. It brings the same meaning. For example:- 사야 하요

To remember easier, we should understand why -야 되다 = should.

 1. 아/어/여 + 야 = only when you do _____.
 2. 되다 = to be possible

 When combined, it means, 'only when you do _____, it works'.

 Which therefore means 'should/have to'

 Why there's 되다 and 돼요?
 The present tense for 되다 is 돼요 :)

Lessons.title: More
pages:
더 [deo] = more
 To say more, you just add 더 before the word. Easy right?
 비싸요 [bi-ssa-yo]= expensive
 더 비싸요 [deo bi-ssa-yo]= more expensive

 예뻐요 [yep-peo-yo] = pretty
 더 예뻐요 [deo yep-peo-yo]= prettier

 착해요 [cha-ka-yo] = nice to people
 더 착해요 [deo cha-ka-yo] = nicer to people

 좋아해요 [joh-a-hae-yo]= like
 더 좋아해요 [deo joh-a-hae-yo] = more like

 빨라요 [ppa-leu-yo]= fast.
 더 빨라요 [deo ppa-leu-yo]  =  faster

Lessons.title: Than (compare)
pages:
보다 [bo-da] = than (compare something). 
 To compare something we use 보다 [bo-da].

 영어는 한국어보다 어려워요
 [yeong-eo-neun han-gug-eo-bo-da eo-ryeo-wo-yo.]
 English is more difficult than Korean.

 영어 [yeong-eo] = English
 한국어 [han-gu-geo] = Korean
 보다 [bo-da] = than
 어려워요 [eo-ryeo-wo-yo] = difficult

 To compare, we say A + B + 보다 + description/adjective

More examples:-

 오늘은 어제보다 추워요
 [o-neu-reun eo-je-bo-da chu-wo-yo.]
 Today is colder than yesterday.
 추워요 [chu-wo-yo] = cold
 오늘 [o-neu] = today
 어제 [eo-je] = yesterday

 수박은 사과보다 더 비싸요
 [su-ba-geun sa-gwa-bo-da deo bi-ssa-yo]
 Watermelon is more expensive than apple.
 수박 [su-bag] = watermelon
 사과 [sa-gwa] = apple
 비싸요 [bi-ssa-yo] = expensive
 You can add 더 to the sentence, but it's not always necessary.

Lessons.title: Ask politely
pages:
Ask someone do something politely = (으)세요
 To ask someone to do something politely, we use -(으)세요 [-(eu)se-yo].

 어서오세요? [eo-seo-o-se-yo]
 Welcome
 안녕히 가세요  [an-nyeong-hi ga-se-yo]
 Goodbye
 주세요  [ju-se-yo]
 Please give

 These phrases are familiar to you right? But did you noticed why there's 세요 in those phrases earlier?  Now you understand. 

 When to use (으)세요 or 세요?

Verb ending with consonant, we use 으세요
 Verb ending with vowel, we use 세요
 Verb ending with ㄹ, we drop the ㄹ and add 세요

 More examples:-
 팔다 [pal-da] = to sell
 파세요 [pa-se-yo] = Please sell it

 공부하세요 [gong-bu-ha-se-yo]
 Please do your studies

 내일 세 시에 오세요 [nae-il se si-e o-se-yo.]
 Please come at 3 o'clock tomorrow

 쉬세요 [swi-se-yo] = Please get some rest
 접으세요 [jeo-beu-se-yo] = Please fold it

Lessons.title: Still
pages:
아직 [a-jik] = Still
 We use 아직 [a-jik] to say still doing something. For example:- 

 아직 안 했어요
  [a-jik an hae-sseo-yo]
  I still haven't done it

 아직 몰라요
 [a-jik mol-la-yo]
 I still don't know

 아직 두 시예요
 [a-jik du si-ye-yo]
 It’s still 2 o’clock

You can emphasize the 'still' meaning by using  아직도 [a-jik-do]

 아직 몰라요?
 [a-jik mol-la-yo?]
 You still don't know yet?

 아직도 몰라요?
 [a-jik-do mol-la-yo?]
 You still don't know yet? How is it possible you still don't know?

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's revision day again

Lessons.title: Already
pages:
벌써 [beol-sseo] = already

 벌써 열 시예요?
 [beol-sseo yeol si-ye-yo?]
 It's already 10 o'clock?
 벌써 왔어요?

 [beol-sseo  wass-eo-yo?]
 You already came?

 You can use 이미 [i-mi] to replace 벌써 too. It brings the same meaning = already. However  for 이미, you use when you are aware of the fact already. For example

 수진은 이미 학교를 떠났어요
 [su-jin-eun i-mi hak-gyo-reul ddeo-nass-o-yo]
 Sujin already left school (you are already aware of it and telling someone the fact)

Lessons.title: In case / If
pages:
To say 'if' in Korean, we have to use 2 expression.
 1. 만약 [man-yak] (to be added before the verb)
 2. (으)면 [-(eu)myeon] (to be joined after the verb)

 Let's look at the example below:-
 자다 [ja-da] = to sleep
 자면 [ja-myeon] = if sleep
 만약 지금 자면 [man-yak ji-geum ja-myeon]
 In case I sleep

 만약 actually means 'in case', but can mean 'if' too

 만약 내일 저는 오면
 [man-yak nae-il na-neun o-myeon]
 If I come tomorrow

만약 지금 비가 오면
 [man-yak ji-geum bi-ga o-myeon]
 If it rains now

 If the sentence is short, you can drop 만약, and just use 지금 비가 오면. To make things clear, we add 만약.

 You can also use past tense and future tense with this. For example:-
 내일 안 오면, 후회할 거예요
 [nae-il an o-myeon hu-hoe-hal geo-ye-yo.]
 If you don't come tomorrow, you will regret it.

지금 안 먹으면, 배고플거예요
 [ji-geum an meo-geu-myeon, bae-go-peul-geo-ye-yo]
 If you don't eat now, you will hungry

  지금 비가 오면, 집에 있을 거예요
 [ji-geum bi-ga o-myeon, ji-be i-sseul geo-ye-yo]
 If it rains now, I will go home

Lessons.title: All
pages:
다 [da] = all

 We just add 다 to mean 'all'.

 다 했어요. [da hae-sseo-yo.]
 I have done all.

 다 주세요. [da ju-se-yo.]
 Please give me all.

 다 샀어요 [da sa-sseo-yo]
 Bought all.

 다 먹어요 [da meo-go-yo]
 Eat all

Lessons.title: Self Introduction
pages:
Self introduction = 자기소개 [ja-gi-so-gae]

 After learning so much, today we will try to build some sentences by introducing yourself.

 저는 연아예요.
 [jeo-neun yeon-a-ye-yo.]
 I'm Yeona.

 저는 선생님이에요
 [jeo-neun seon-saeng-nim-i-e-yo.]
 I'm a teacher.

 저는 20살이에요 [jeo-neun seu-mu-sal-i-e-yo.]
 I am 20 years old.

저는 언니가 있어요.
 [jeo-neun eon-ni-ga i-sseo-yo.]
 I have an older sister.

 저는 취미가 수영이에요
 [jeo-neun chwi-mi-ga su-yeong-i-e-yo]
 My hobby is swimming

 저는 서울에 살아요.
 [ jeo-neun seo-u-re sa-ra-yo.]
 I live in Seoul.

Lessons.title: Exam!
pages: Congratulations for reaching 2 month of this course. By now, you should be able to understand quite alot of Korean.  Let's take an exam and graduate to 3rd month course, which will be coming soon!

Lessons.title: Don't do
pages:
Verb + 지 마세요 [... ji ma-se-yo] = Don't do something

 말다 [mal-da] = to quit, stop doing

 If you remember 세요 [se-yo], it's used to ask someone to do something. So when combined 말다 + (으)세요, you get 마세요 [ma-se-yo].

 However, when used with verb, you need add 지 마세요 [ji ma-se-yo]

 Examples:-
 가지 마세요 [ga-ji ma-se-yo]
 Don't go

 하지 마세요 [ha-ji ma-se-yo]
 Don't do

걱정하지 마세요 [geok-jeong-ha-ji ma-se-yo]
 Don't worry

 웃지 마세요 [ut-ji ma-se-yo]
 Don't laugh

 울지 마세요 [ul-ji ma-se-yo]
 Don't cry

 떠나지 마세요 [tteo-na-ji ma-se-yo]
 Don't leave

Lessons.title: Do ... for me
pages:
주세요 = Please do ... for me
 In previous month, you learned that (으)세요 is to used to ask people do something.

 For example:-
 오세요 [o-se-yo]
 Please come

 If you use 아/어/여 + 주세요, it will mean 'please do something for me'.

 For example:-
 와 주세요 [wa ju-se-yo]
 Please come (because of me / do me a favor)

 해 주세요 [hae ju-se-yo]
 Please do for me

김치 사세요 [gim-chi sa-se-yo]
 Please buy kimchi for yourself / for someone

 김치 사 주세요
 [gim-chi sa ju-se-yo]
 Please buy kimchi for me.

 As you have noticed, you will need to combine 아/어/여 to the verb before adding 주세요.

 By now, you should be familiar when to use 아/어/여 when combining with verb. If you don't, you will need to revise previous months lessons:)

More examples:-
 같이 가 주세요 [ga-chi ga ju-se-yo]
 Please go together (for me)

 도와 주세요 [do-wa ju-se-yo]
 Please help me (for me)

 주세요 comes from 주다 [ju-da] which means 'to give'. So, when combined 주세요 with verb, it means do something(verb) for me.

Lessons.title: Something, someday ...
pages:
Today, you will learn how to say 'someday, something, someone, somewhere'. Just add -ㄴ가 (-n-ga) to the verb

 언제 (when) + -ㄴ가 = 언젠가
 [eon-jen-ga]
 someday

 뭐 (what) + -ㄴ가 = 뭔가
 [mwon-ga]
 something

 누구 (who) + -ㄴ가 = 누군가
 [nu-gun-ga]
 someone

 어디 (where) + -ㄴ가 = 어딘가
 [eo-din-ga]
 somewhere

Easy right? Let's try to build some sentence with these.

 여기 어딘가에 있어요
 [yeo-gi eo-din-ga-e i-sseo-yo]
 It's somewhere here.

 누군가 했어요
 [nu-gun-ga hae-sseo-yo]
 Someone did it.

 뭔가 재미있어요
 [mwon-ga jae-mi-iss-eo-yo]
 Something is interesting.

 언젠가 한국에 가고 싶어요.
 [eon-jen-ga han-gug-ge ga-go si-peo-yo]
 I want to go to Korea someday.

Lessons.title: Too much
pages:
너무 [neo-mu] = too (much)
 We use 너무 [neo-mu] to mean 'too much/very'. For example:-

 너무 비싸요. [neo-mu bi-ssa-yo]
 It's too expensive

 너무 빨라요. [neo-mu ppal-la-yo]
 It's too fast

 너무 맛있어요. [neo-mu ma-si-sseo-yo]
 It's very tasty

 너무 멋있어요 [neo-mu meo-si-sseo-yo.]
 Too cool/handsome.

 너무 더워요. [neo-mu deo-wo-yo.]
 It’s too hot. / It’s very hot

Lessons.title: Up, bottom, top, under, next
pages:
From last month lesson, we have learned 어디 있어요? [eo-di i-sseo-yo?] = Where is it?
 Today, we will learn how to describe the position

 앞 [ap] = front
 뒤 [dwi] = back
 위 [wi] = top
 밑 [mit] = bottom
 옆 [yeop] = side

 To use in sentence, we will need to add location particle 에 [-e]. For example:

 앞에 [a-pe] = in front of
 뒤에 [dwi-e] = behind
 위에 [wi-e] = top of
 밑에 [mit-e] = under
 옆에 [yeop-e] = side
Let's build some sentences

 나무 앞에 있어요
 [na-mu a-pe i-sseo-yo.]
 It’s in front of the tree.

 나무 밑에 있어요
 [na-mu mi-te i-sseo-yo.]
 It’s under the tree

 나무 뒤에 있어요
 [na-mu dwi-e i-sseo-yo.]
 It’s behind the tree

나무 옆에 있어요
 [na-mu yeop-e i-sseo-yo.]
 It’s next to the tree

 나무 위에 있어요
 [na-mu wi-e i-sseo-yo.]
 It’s on top of the tree

 나무 [na-mu] = tree

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's revision day again!

Lessons.title: Grammar
pages:
(으)로 [(eu)ro].
 (으)로 [-(eu)ro] can have various function as below:-
 1. With (The ingredient something is made of)
 2. The direction someone is going
 3. The reason of something happened

 Let see examples for better understanding

 나무 [na-mu] + 로 + 만들다 [man-deul-da]
 나무로 만들다 [na-mu-ro man-deul-da]
 to make something with wood

 나무 [na-mu] = wood
 만들다 [man-deul-da] = to make

오른쪽 [o-leun-jjog] + 으로 + 가다 [ga-da]
 오른쪽으로 가다 [o-leun-jjo-geu-ro ga-da]
 to go to the right

 연필 [yeon-pil] + 로 + 쓰다 [sseu-da]
 연필로 쓰다 [yeon-pil-ro sseu-da]
 to write with pencil

 노래 [nolae] + 로 + 유명하다 [yu-myeong-ha-da]
 노래로 유명하다 [no-lae-ro yu-myeong-ha-da]
 to be famous by song

 오른쪽 [o-leun-jjog] = right side
 연필 [yeon-pil] = pencil
 노래 [nolae] = song
 유명하다 [yu-myeong-ha-da] = to be famous

When to use 으로 or 로?
 For nouns ending with a consonant we use 으로
 For nouns ending in a vowel or the consonant ㄹ, we use 로

 Let's see more sample sentences.

 오늘 버스로 왔어요?
 [o-neul beo-seu-ro wa-sseo-yo?]
 Today you came by bus?

 상상을 현실로 만들다
 [sang-sang-eul hyeon-sil-ro man-deul-da]
 Make imagination a reality

 현실 [hyeon-sil] = reality
 상상 [sang-sang] = imagination

Lessons.title: Approximately
pages:
쯤 [jjeum] = approximately

 쯤 [jjeum] means approximately / around / about, and we use it after noun. For example

 백 원쯤 [baek won-jjeum]
 About 100 won

 다섯 시쯤 [da-seot si-jjeum]
 Around 5 o'clock

 백 명쯤 [baek myeong-jjeum]
 Approximately 100 people

We can use 정도 [jeong-do] too, that has the same meaning.

 천 원 정도 [cheon won jeong-do]
 Around 1000 won

 다섯 시 정도 [da-seot si jeong-do]
 Approximately 5 o'clock

 We can also use 약 [yak], that also has the same meaning but it's used before noun

 약 한 달 [yak han dal] = about a month

Lessons.title: Before
pages:
전에 [jeo-ne] = Before
 We use 전에 [jeo-ne] before a noun.

 월요일 전에 [wo-ryo-il jeo-ne]
 before Monday

 수업 전에 [su-eop jeo-ne]
 before class

 To use on a verb, we add 기 전에 [gi jeo-ne]

 학교에 가기 전에 [hag-gyo-e ga-gi jeo-ne]
 Before going to school

 여기 오기 전에 [yeo-gi o-gi jeo-ne]
 Before coming here

 공부하기 전에 먹을 거예요
 [gong-bu-ha-gi jeo-ne meog-eul geo-ye-yo]
 Eat before you study

Lessons.title: Similar
pages:
비슷하다 [bi-seu-ta-da] = to be similar
 To say A is similar to B, we use 랑 or 하고 along with 비슷하다

 A랑 비슷해요. [A-rang bi-seu-tae-yo.]
 It’s similar to A.
 B하고 비슷해요. [B-ha-go bi-seu-tae-yo.]
 It’s similar to B.

 부산은 서울하고 비슷해요?
 [bu-san-eun seo-ul-ha-go bi-seut-hae-yo?]
 Is Busan similar to Seoul?

 저 사람은 미나하고 비슷해요
 [jeo sa-ram-eun mi-na-ha-go bi-seut-hae-yo]
That person is similar to Mina

Lessons.title: Same
pages:
같다 [gat-da] = to be the same
 Similar to previous lesson, we will use 랑 or 하고 along with 같다

 A랑 같다요
 [A-rang ga-ta-yo]
 It’s same as A.

 이거하고 저거는 같아요
 [i-go-ha-go jeo-go-neun ga-ta-yo]
 A and B are the same.

If you use 같다 without 랑 or 하고, it will mean 'like something', instead of same

 미나는 천사 같아요
 [mi-na-neun cheon-sa ga-ta-yo.]
 Mina is like an angel.

 고양이 같아요.
 [go-yang-i ga-ta-yo]
 Like a cat

 거짓말 같아요.
 [geo-jit-mal ga-ta-yo]
 Like a lie

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Let's revise what we have learned.

Lessons.title: If so
pages:
그러면 [geu-reo-myeon] = in that case, if so

 그러면 is a combination of 그렇다 [geu-reot-ta], which means 'to be so' + (으)면. We have already introduced (으)면 in last month lessons, which means 'if'. So when combine, 그렇다 + 면 we get 그러면

 Let's see some example
 그럼면 언제 바빠요?
 [geu-reom-myeon eon-je ba-ppa-yo?]
 If so, when you are busy?

 그럼면 이제 어떻게 해요?
 [geu-reom-myeon i-je eo-tteo-ke hae-yo?]
 If so, what do we do now?

We can also use 그럼 [geu-reom] as short form.

 그럼 이제 바빠요?
 [geu-reom i-je ba-ppa-yo?]
 If so, are you busy now?

 그럼 김치도 좋아해요?
 [geu-reom gim-chi-do jo-a-hae-yo?]
 If so, do you like kimchi too?

Lessons.title: But still, nonetheless
pages:
그래도 [geu-rae-do] = But still, nonetheless

 그래 = 그렇게 해 (to do that) +  도 = too. When combined you get 그래도, which means even if that happen, you still ...

 Let's see example:- 
 피곤해요. 그래도 갈 거예요?
 [pi-gon-hae-yo. geu-lae-do gal geo-ye-yo?]
 I'm tired. Nonetheless, are you still going?

 한국어는 어려워요. 그래도 한국어를 공부하고 있어요.
 [han-gu-geo-neun eo-ryeo-wo-yo. geu-rae-do han-gu-geo-reul gong-bu-ha-go i-sseo-yo.]
 Korean is difficult. But still, I'm still studying Korean.

요즘 아파요. 그래도 일해요.
[yo-jeum a-pa-yo. geu-rae-do il-hae-yo]
 I'm sick these days. But still, I'm working.

 아파요 [a-pa-yo]= sick
 요즘 [yo-jeum] = recently

Lessons.title: Grammar (Making verb into noun)
pages:
We use -는 것 [-neun geot] to change verb into noun

 By changing verb into noun, it can mean
 1. the act of doing something
 2. the thing you doing

 For example:-
 보다 [bo-da] = to see
 보는 것 [bo-neun geot] = the act of seeing, the thing you see

 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat
 먹는 것 [meok-neun geot] = the act of eating, the thing you eat

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가는 것 [ga-neun geot] = the act of going
보는것의 비밀
 [bo-neun-geos-ui bi-mil]
 The secret of seeing

 난 쇠고기가 먹는 것 좋아해요
 [nan soe-go-gi-ga meog-neun geot joh-a-hae-yo]
 I like eating beef

 잘 사는 것
 [jal sa-neun geot]
 Living well

 너를 알아가는 것
 [neo-leul al-a-ga-neun geot]
 Knowing you

Instead of using 는 것, you can also use 는 거 for ease of pronunciation

 보는 거 아니에요
 [bo-neun geo a-ni-e-yo]
 Not looking

 여기에서 먹는거  맛있어요
 [yeo-gi-e-seo meog-neun-geo mas-iss-eo-yo]
 It's delicious eating here.

 Please note that 는 것 is only used for present tense. For past tense, we will use (으)ㄴ 것 and (으)ㄹ 것 for future tense.

Lessons.title: Shall we?
pages:
(으)ㄹ까요? [(eu)l-kka-yo?] = Shall we?

 (으)ㄹ까요? [(eu)l-kka-yo?] can have few meanings depending on context
 1. Shall we ... ?
 2. Asking oneself question
 3. Ask a question and attracting others attention

 When to use (으)ㄹ or ㄹ?
 For verb ending with consonant, we use 을까요
 For verb ending with vowel, we use ㄹ까요
 For verb ending with ㄹ, we use 까요

 Examples:-
 내일 우리 밥 먹을까요?
 [nae-il u-ri bab meog-eul-kka-yo?]
 Shall we eat dinner tomorrow?

오늘 비가 올까요?
 [o-neul bi-ga ol-kka-yo?]
 I wonder it will rain today?

 커피 마실까요?
 [keo-pi ma-sil-kka-yo?]
 Shall we drink coffee?

 여긴 왜 유명할까요?
 [yeo-gin wae yu-myeong-hal-kka-yo?]
 Why here is famous?

Lessons.title: After
pages:
다음에 [da-eu-me] After
 To say after doing something, we use
 Verb + (으)ㄴ + 다음에

 받다 [bat-da] = to receive
 받은 다음에 [ba-deun da-eu-me] = after receiving

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 간 다음에 [gan da-eu-me] = after going

 We can also use 후에 [hu-e] or 뒤에 [dwi-e] to replace 다음에.

 간 뒤에 [gan dwi-e] = after going
 간 후에 [gan hu-e] = after going

보다 [bo-da] = watch
 본 다음에 [bon da-eu-me] = after watching

 먹다 [meog-da] = eat
 먹은 다음에 [meo-geun da-eu-me] = after eating

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 한 다음에 [han da-eu-me] = after doing

 Let's build longer sentence.

 영화 본 다음에 우리 소주 마셔요
 [yeong-hwa bon da-eu-me u-ri so-ju ma-syeo-yo.]
 After watching movie, let's drink soju.
이거 한 후에 뭐 할 거예요?
 [i-geo han hu-e mwo hal geo-ye-yo?]
 After doing this, what you will do?

 점심을 먹은 뒤에, 집에 갈 거예요
 [jeom-si-meul meo-geun dwi-e, ji-be gal geo-ye-yo]
 After having lunch, I will go home

 Below are the meaning of these 'after'
 다음 [da-eum] = next
 후 [hu] = after
 뒤 [dwi] = behind

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Let's revise what we have learned

Lessons.title: Grammar - Link Verbs
pages:
Do you remember 그리고 [geu-ri-go]? Yes, it means 'and' / 'and then'. For example

 친구를 만났어요. 그리고 집에 갔어요
 [chin-gu-reul man-na-sseo-yo. geu-ri-go jib-e gass-eo-yo]
 I met friend yesterday. And then I went home.

 How to join this 2 sentence together and making it shorter? We use 고 [go]

 Taking example above, 만났어요, we turn into 만났고

 친구를 만났고, 집에 갔어요
 [chin-gu-reul man-nat-go jib-e gass-eo-yo]
 I met friend, and then I went home.
Please note that 만났고 is in past tense. Usually we use present tense for the first verb and past/future on the last verb. So we can also use 만나고 instead of 만났고

 친구를 만나고, 집에 갔어요
 [chin-gu-reul man-na-go, jib-e gass-eo-yo]
 I met friend, and then I went home.

 Let's look at more examples
 영화를 볼 거예요. 그리고 학교에 갈 거예요
 [yeong-hwa-reul bol geo-ye-yo. geu-ri-go hag-gyo-e gal geo-ye-yo] =

 영화를 보고,학교에 갈 거예요
 [yeong-hwa-reul bol-geo, hag-gyo-e gal geo-ye-yo]
 I watch a movie and then go to school.

친구를 만났어요. 그리고 밥을 먹었어요.
 [chin-gu-reul man-nass-eo-yo. geu-ri-go ba-beul meo-geo-sseo-yo] =

 친구를 만나고, 밥을 먹었어요
 [chin-gu-reul man-na-go, ba-beul meo-geo-sseo-yo]
 I met friend, and then we ate rice (having a meal).

 커피 마시고, 케익 먹고, 맥주 마시고, 밥 먹었어요
 [keo-pi ma-si-go, ke-ig meog-go, maeg-ju ma-si-go, bab meog-eoss-eo-yo]
 I drank coffee, and eat cake, and drank beer, and ate rice.

어제는 한국에 가고, 내일은 태국에 갈 거예요
 [eo-je-neun han-gu-ge ga-go, nae-il-eun tae-gu-ge gal geo-ye-yo]
 Yesterday I went to Korea, and today I will go to Thailand.

Lessons.title: Grammar - Future Tense II
pages:
In previous month, you have learned about future tense. So what future tense we will learn today? Before that, let's refresh.

 We combined verb + (으)ㄹ 거예요 to become future tense. For example

 할 거예요 [hal geo-ye-yo] = will do

 Today we will use (으)ㄹ게요.

 할게요 [hal-ge-yo] = will do (this is used as reaction after someone spoke something, or you hope for reply)

 For example, someone told you to do something. Then you reply 할게요 = I will do

Or you say 할게요, hoping someone will reply you on that sentence.

 More examples:-

 저 갈게요 [jeo gal-ge-yo]
 (Since you say so) I will go
 I will go (If you don't mind)

 공부할게요 [gong-bu-hal-ge-yo]
 (Since you say so) I will study
 I will study (Waiting if the person have anything to say on this)

 공부할 거예요 [gong-bu-hal geo-ye-yo.]
 I will study (regardless what the person say or didn't say)

먹을게요 [meog-eul-ge-yo]
 (Since you say so) I will eat
 I will eat (Waiting if the person have anything to say on this)

 마실게요 [ma-sil-ge-yo]
 (Since you say so) I will drink
 I will drink (Waiting if the person have anything to say on this)

Lessons.title: For sake of
pages:
위해 / 위해서 [wi-hae] / [wi-hae-seo] = in order to/for
 To mean 'In order to', 'for the sake of', we use 위해서 [wi-hae-seo] or 위해 [wi-hae].

 To use this with verb, we use
 Verb + 기 위해/위해서

 학교에 가기 위해서
 [hag-gyo-e ga-gi wi-hae-seo]
 In order to go to school

 먹기 위해서
 [meog-gi wi-hae-seo]
 In order to eat

To use this with noun, we use
 Noun + 을/를 위해/위해서

 학교를 위해서
 [hag-gyo-reul wi-hae-seo]
 For the sake of school

 건강을 위해서
 [geon-gang-eul wi-hae-seo]
 For the sake of health

 Let's try longer sentence
 저는 태국에 가기 위해서 열심히 일해요
 [jeo-neun tae-gu-ge ga-gi wi-hae-seo yeol-si-mi il-hae-yo.]
 I work hard in order to go to Thailand

 열심히 [yeol-si-mi] = diligent
 일해요 [il-hae-yo] = work

건강을 위해서 열심히 운동하고 있어요
 [geon-gang-eul wi-hae-seo yeol-si-mi un-dong-ha-go i-sseo-yo.]
 For the sake of health, I exercise diligently.
 건강 [geon-gang] = health

 돈을 위해서 일해요
 [don-eul wi-hae-seo il-hae-yo]
 I work for money

 You can also use 위해 to replace 위해서 for all the examples we have gone through.

 For your knowledge, 위해 / 위해서 comes from 위하다 [wi-ha-da] which means 'to do something for the benefit of something'

Lessons.title: It might
pages:
(으)ㄹ 수도 있다 [(eu)l su-do it-da] = it might be possible

 Previously you have learned that (으)ㄹ 수 있다 means 'can do'. And 수 [su] in this context means, have an idea of solving something.
 By adding 도 [do] = too, you get the meaning of 'it might be possible'

 만나다 [man-na-da] = to meet
 만날 수도 있다 [man-nal su-do it-da]
 might meet

 오다 [o-da] = to come
 올 수도 있다 [ol su-do it-da]
 might come

 먹다 [o-da] = to eat
 먹을 수도 있다 [meog-eul su-do it-da]
 might eat

하다 [ha-da] = to do
 할 수도 있다 [hal su-do it-da] = might do

 Let's build longer sentence
 미나는 알 수도 있어요.
 [mi-na-neun al su-do i-sseo-yo]
 Mina might know

 다음주 다시 만날 수도 있어요
 [da-eum-ju da-si man-nal su-do i-sseo-yo] Let's meet again next week.

 미나는 내일 올 수도 있어요
 [mi-na-neun ol su-do i-sseo-yo.]
 Mina might come tomorrow

Lessons.title: Grammar - Even though
pages:
On previous lesson, you have learned 그래도 [geu-rae-do] = nevertheless. Today, we will shorten it and to join sentence again

 We will use 아/어/여 + 도 [a/eo/yeo + do]

 Verb ending with ㅗ or ㅏ, we use 아도
 Verb ending with other vowels, we use 어도
 Verb ending with 하, we use 여도

 요즘 아파요. 그래도 일해요.
 [yo-jeum a-pa-yo. geu-rae-do il-hae-yo]
 I'm sick these days. But still, I work.

 요즘 아파도, 일해요.
 [yo-jeum a-pa-do, il-hae-yo]
 Even though I'm sick these days, I still work.

한국어는 어려워요. 그래도 한국어를 공부하고 있어요.
 [han-gu-geo-neun eo-ryeo-wo-yo. geu-rae-do han-gu-geo-reul gong-bu-ha-go i-sseo-yo.]
 Korean is difficult. But still, I'm still studying Korean.

 한국어는 어려워도, 한국어를 공부하고 있어요.
 [han-gu-geo-neun eo-ryeo-wo-do, han-gu-geo-reul gong-bu-ha-go i-sseo-yo.]
 Even though Korean is difficult, I'm still studying Korean.

피곤해요. 그래도 갈 거예요.
 [pi-gon-hae-yo. geu-lae-do gal geo-ye-yo]
 I'm tired. Nonetheless, I am still going

 피곤해도 갈 거예요
 [pi-gon-hae-do gal geo-ye-yo]
 Even though I'm tired, I am still going

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: After learning a lot of grammar lessons, it's time to revision!

Lessons.title: Expressing surprised/thought
pages:
If you watch movies or lyrics, you will noticed alot of ending with 네요 [ne-yo].

 네요 [ne-yo] is used to express surprised or your thought about something

 For example
 커요 [keo-yo]= big (stating the fact)
 크네요 [keu-ne-yo] = big (but you are surprised it's big / you found out it's big)

 While 커요 can also mean big (surprised) with right tone, it can't bring out the surprised / thought meaning if it's written. Right?

Please note the way to join the words. By now you should be good in joining these

 크다 + 어요 = 커요 big (stating a fact)
 크다 + 네요 = 크네요 big (expressed surprised)

 있다 + 어요 = 있어요 have (stating a fact)
 있다 + 네요 = 있네요 have (expressed surprised)

 맛있다 + 어요 = 맛있어요 delicious (stating a fact)
 맛있다 + 네요 = 맛있네요 delicious (expressed surprised)

More examples:-

 이거 맛있네요.
 [i-geo mas-iss-ne-yo.]
 This is delicious (Expressing surprised / your thought)

 오늘은 너무 춥네요.
 [o-neul-eun neo-mu chup-ne-yo.]
 Today is very cold (Expressing surprised / your thought)

 이 영화 재미있네요.
 [i yeong-hwa jae-mi-it-ne-yo.]
 This movie is interesting (Expressing surprised / your thought)

Lessons.title: Let's
pages:
Verb + 자 [ja] = Let's

 To say 'lets do something', we use 자 [ja]. Please note that this is 반말 [ban-mal](casual language), and can only be used with someone close to you, such as friends. You will notice alot of 반말 in movies, dramas too.

 가요 [ga-yo] = go
 가자 [ga-ja]= Let's go

 놀어요 [nol-eo-yo] = play
 놀자 [nol-ja]= Let's play

 먹어요 [meog-eo-yo] = eat
 먹자 [meog-ja]= Let's eat

 해요 [hae-yo] = do
 하자 [ha-ja]= Let's do

사요 [sa-yo] = buy
 사자 [sa-ja]= Let's buy

 More examples:-
 이거 사자
 [i-geo sa-ja]
 Let's buy this

 같이 가자
 [ga-chi ga-ja]
 Let's go together

 내일은 쉬자
 [nae-il-reun swi-ja]
 Let's rest tomorrow

 저녁 먹자
 [jeo-nyeog meog-ja]
 Let's eat dinner

Lessons.title: Grammar
pages:
Today we will look at 데 [de]. Before looking into the usage, let's look at how to join with verbs.

 는데 is used after verbs, after 있다 and 없다, and after 았 (all past tense) or 겠.

 있다 [it-da] = 있는데 [it-neun-de]
 하다 [ha-da] = 하는데 [ha-neun-de]
 했어요 [haess-o-yo] = 했는데 [haess-neun-de]

 은데 is used after adjectives that end with consonant except ㄹ

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] = 예쁜데 [ye-ppeun-de]
 많다 [manh-da] = 많은데 [manh-eun-de]

ㄴ데 is used after adjectives that end with vowel or ㄹ(ㄹ will be dropped), and after 이다  and 아니다

 크다 [keu-da] = 큰데 [keun-de]

 금요일이에요 [geum-yo-il-i-e-yo]
 = 금요일인데 [geum-yo-il-in-de]

 It will take a while to understand and remember all this rules. So, don't worry. Let's us look at the usage for better understanding.
Usage:-
 1. Explain the background of situation before making a suggestion / question.
 내일 금요일인데, 뭐 할 거예요?
 [nae-il geum-ryo-il-in-de, mwo hal geo-ye-yo?]
 Tomorrow is Friday, what will you do?

 질문이 있는데, 어디에 가요? 
 [jil-mun-i iss-neun-de, eo-di-e ga-yo?]
 I have a question, where you will go?
 질문 [jil-mun] = question

 2. Explain the situation before explaining what had happened
 어제 피곤하는데, 일찍 잤어요
 [eo-je pi-gon-ha-neun-de, il-jjig jass-eo-yo] I am tired yesterday, so I slept early
 일찍 [il-jjig] = early

3. Showing a contrasting situation with the action
 아직 7시인데, 벌써 잤어요
 [a-jik il-gop-si-in-de beol-sseo jass-eo-yo]
 It's still 7 o'clock, I slept already

 4. Asking a question and expecting and answer
 지금 어디에 있는데?
 [ji-geum eo-di-e it-neun-de?]
 Where are you now?

 5. Statement but expecting a reply.
 내일 바쁜데
 [nae-il ba-ppeun-de]
 I'm busy tomorrow (expecting a reply)

6. Expressing surprise
 그림자를 봤는데
 [geu-lim-ja-leul bwatt-neun-de]
 I saw a shadow
 그림자 [geu-lim-ja] = shadow

Lessons.title: Casual language
pages:
After a long lesson yesterday, we will have a light one today. In 'Let's' lesson, we have explained that 반말 (casual language) is used for people close to you such as close friends.

 Let's look at more 반말 example phrases

 안녕하세요 [an-nyeong-ha-se-yo] ---> 
 안녕 [an-nyeong]
 Hello

 안녕히 가세요 [an-nyeong-hi ga-se-yo] ---> 
 안녕 [an-nyeong] / 잘 가 [jal ga]
 Goodbye (you staying people leaving)

 안녕히 계세요. [an-nyeong-hi ge-se-yo] ---> 
 안녕 [an-nyeong] / 잘 있어. [jal i-sseo]
 Goodbye (you leaving people staying)

아니요 [a-ni-yo] ---> 
 아니 [a-ni] / 아니야 [a-ni-ya]
 No

 저 [jeo] ---> 
 나 [na]
 I

 씨 [ssi] ---> 
 너 [neo]
 You

Lessons.title: Grammar
pages:
When verb has ㄷ ending  and followed by vowel, we remove ㄷ, and replace with ㄹ. For example

 듣다 [deud-da] = to listen
 들어요 [deul-eo-yo] = listen

 묻다 [mut-da] = to ask
 물어요 [mul-eo-yo] = ask

 싣다 [sit-da] = to load
 실어요 [sil-eo-yo] = load

 깨닫다 [kkae-dat-da] = to realise
 깨달았어요 [kkae-dal-as-seo-yo] = realised

 걷다 [geot-da] = to walk
 걸었어요 [geo-reo-seo-yo] = walked

However, there's some irregular verb that remain ㄷ, and NOT replaced by ㄹ. Such as

 받다 [bat-da] = to receive
 받아요 [ba-da-yo] = receive

 닫다 [dad-da] = to close
 닫아요 [da-da-yo] = close

 믿다 [mid-da] = to believe
 믿어요 [mi-deo-yo] = believe

 More examples next page:-

걷는 것 싫어요 [geot-neun geot shi-reo-yo]
 I hate walking
 ㄷ doesn't change to ㄹ because it's followed by consonant 는

 걸었어요 [geo-reo-seo-yo]
 walked
 ㄷ change to ㄹ because it's followed by vowel 었

 듣고 있어요 [deud-go-i-sseo-yo]
 I am listening
 ㄷ doesn't change to ㄹ because it's followed by consonant 고

 듣었어요 [deud-eo-sseo-yo]
 listened
 ㄷ change to ㄹ because it's followed by vowel 었

Lessons.title: Exam
pages: We definitely learn alot of grammar this month. So, it's time to take an exam to wrap up this month. 4th month will be coming soon!

Lessons.title: Room
pages:
Today we will learn about 실 [sil]. 실 is related to rooms, which can mean room or an area of enclosed space. There's alot type of rooms that has the word 실. For example

 교실 [gyo-sil] = classroom

 사무실 [sa-mu-sil] = office

 병실 [byeong-sil] = hospital's room

 화장실[hwa-jang-sil] = toilet (direct translation is makeup room)

 연습실 [yeon-seup-sil] = practise room

대기실 [dae-gi-sil] = waiting room

 교무실 [gyo-mu-sil] = teacher's office

 회의실 [hoe-ui-sil] = meeting room

 미용실 [mi-yong-sil] = beauty room

 실내 [sil-nae] = indoor

 실외 [sil-oe] = outdoor

Lessons.title: Learning
pages:
Let's build more vocabulary. Today we will learn 학 [hak]. 학 is related to learning. For example

 학생 [hak-saeng] = student

 학원 [ha-gwon] = private institute

 학교 [hak-gyo] = school

 학기 [hak-gi] = semester

 학자 [hak-ja] = scholar

 과학 [gwa-hak] = science

 수학 [su-hak] = mathematics

 어학 [eo-hak] = language learning

유학 [yu-hak] = studying abroad

 유학생 [yu-hak-saeng] = student studying abroad

 전학 [jeon-hak] = change school

 장학금 [jang-hak-geum] = scholarship

 장학생 [jang-hak-saeng] = student on scholarship

Lessons.title: The more A, the more B
pages:
To say the more [A], the more [B], we use A + 을수록 [-eul-su-rok] + B

 Verb ending in vowel, we use ㄹ 수록
 Verb ending in consonant, we use 을수록
 Verb ending with ㄹ, we use 수록

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] + ㄹ수록 [eul-su-rok]
 예쁠수록  [ye-ppeu-su-rok]
 the more prettier, the more ...

 맛있다 [ma-sit-da] + 을수록 [eul-su-rok]
 맛있을수록 [ma-si-sseul-su-rok]
 the more delicious, the more ...

 가다 [ga-da] + ㄹ수록 [eul-su-rok]
 갈수록 [gal-su-rok]
 the more you go, the more ...

비싸다 [bi-ssa-da] + -ㄹ수록 [eul-su-rok]
 비쌀수록  [bi-ssal-su-rok]
 the more expensive, the more ...

 Let's build full sentence

 맛있을수록 잘 팔려요
 [ma-si-sseul-su-rok jal pal-lyeo-yo]
 The more delicious it is, the more it sells

 예쁠수록 인기가 많아요
 [ye-ppeu-su-rok in-gi-ga ma-na-yo]
 The more pretty you are, the more famous you are

 비쌀수록 좋아요
 [bi-ssal-su-rok jo-a-yo]
 The more expensive it is, the better
미나는 갈수록 한국어를 잘 해요
 [mi-na-neun gal-su-rok han-gu-geo-reul jal hae-yo]
 Mina keep getting better at Korean

 갈수록 [gal-su-rok] means 'the more you go', but it can also, and usually means 'as time goes by'

Lessons.title: You!
pages:
당신 [dang-sin] = you

 When watching movie, you should hear alot of 당신 [dang-sin]. 당신 means you. But, you must learn when to use this word. Otherwise you will appear awkward or rude

 We use 당신 [dang-sin] when
 1. You are angry at someone
 2. Inside lyric, movie text
 3. Addressing you spouse
 4. Addressing someone who is not in the place in honorific way

 For examples:-

 당신 뭐야?
 [dang-sin mwo-ya?]
 What are you?

당신의 시처럼?
 [dang-sin-ui si-cheo-reom]
 Like your poem (lyric)

 당신의 하우스헬퍼
 [dangsin-ui ha-u-seu-hel-peo]
 Your house helper (movie title)

 당신 바빠요?
 [dang-sin ji-geum eo-di-ye-yo?]
 Honey, are you busy?

Lessons.title: Intention to do
pages:
When we to express an intention or a will to do something, we use (으)ㄹ래요. It's quite similar to 고 싶어요 (want to do something), which you have learned previously.

 Please note that this is only used when you talk with someone in casual setting and not formal.

 Verb ending with vowel, we use -ㄹ래요
 Verb ending with consonant, we use 을래요
 Verb ending with  ㄹ, we use 래요

 집에 갈래요
 [ji-be gal-lae-yo]
 I want to go home

뭐 마실래요?
 [mwo ma-sil-lae-yo?]
 What you want to drink?

 뭐 먹을래요?
 [mwo meog-eul-lae-yo?]
 What you want to eat?

 혼자 할래요
 [hon-ja hal-lae-yo]
 I'll do it alone

 이거 볼래?
 [i-geo bol-lae?]
 You want to see this?

 어디에 만날래?
 [eo-di-e man-nal-lae?]
 Where do we meet?

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Let's revise what we have learned!

Lessons.title: Grammar (Reassure)
pages:
Often times, we will hear or come across 지요 [jiyo]. What does it mean? You use 지요 when

 1. You talk about something and supposing the other person already know about it.

 If it's used in a question, 지요 it means

 1. Both of you know about the something and you are reiterating the fact.
 2. You are asking yourself a question and at the same time asking other people.
 3. You are asking yourself a question.

 Present tense: 지요 [jiyo]
 Past tense: 았/었/였 + 지요
 Future tense: (으)ㄹ 거 + 지요
You can also use  죠 [jyo]. 죠 [jyo] is shortform for 지요 [jiyo].

 For example
 김치 정말 맛있죠.
 [gim-chi jeong-mal ma-sit-jyo]
 Kimchi is delicious (You know the other person thinks kimchi is delicious)

 어제 날씨 춥지요?
 [o-je nal-ssi chup-ji-yo?]
 Yesterday the weather is cold, right? (You know the other person know the weather is cold too)

이거 뭐지요?
 [i-geo mwo-ji-yo?]
 이거 뭐지?
 [i-geo mwo-ji?]
 What is this? (Asking yourself a question)

 재미 없지요.
 [jae-mi eob-ji-yo]
 It's not fun (You know the other person think it's not fun too)

 지금 갈 거 지요.
 [ji-geum gal geo ji-yo]
 I will go now (You know the other person know you will be go now)

Lessons.title: It's impossible ...
pages:
(으)ㄹ 리가 없어요  [(eu)l li-ga eop-seo-yo] = it's impossible that.

 리 [li] means 'logic' or 'reason', so when you add 없어요, it mean's no reason, not logic, which therefore means 'it's impossible that'

As you have guessed, for
 Verb ending with vowel, we use ㄹ 리가 없어요
 Verb ending with consonant, we use 을 리가 없어요
 Verb ending with ㄹ, we use 리가 없어요

 Let's see some examples.

 눈이 오다 [nu-ni o-da] = to snow
 눈이 올 리가 없어요.
 [nu-ni ol li-ga eop-seo-yo.]
 It's impossible to snow

 알다 [al-da] = to know
 알 리가 없어요.
 [al li-ga eop-seo-yo]
 It's impossible he/she know

To make this past tense, we add 을 리가 없어요 after 았/었/였. For example

 왔어요 [wass-eo-yo] = came
 왔을 리가 없어요
 [wass-eul li-ga eop-seo-yo]
 Impossible he/she came

 알았어요 [al-a-sseo-yo] = knew
 알았을 리가 없어요
 [al-a-sseul li-ga eop-seo-yo]
 Impossible he/she knew

For future tense, it's the same structure as present tense

 More examples:

 그럴 리가 없어요.
 [geu-reol li-ga eop-seo-yo.]
 That is impossible

 있었을 리가 없어요.
 [i-sseo-sseul li-ga eop-seo-yo.]
 It's impossible there was

 미나가 할 리가 없어요.
 [mi-na-ga hal li-ga eop-seo-yo]
 It's impossible Mina will do

Lessons.title: It's okay
pages:
괜찮아요 [gwaen-cha-na-yo] = It's okay

 Today lesson is pretty easy. 괜찮아요 [gwaen-cha-na-yo] means it's okay. For sure, you all know what this it right?

 Let's see some example when this can be used
 1. If you are hurt, and you want to say you are okay, you say 괜찮아요.
 2. No thanks. If someone offered you something and you refuse politely, you say 괜찮아요.
 3. If you want to tell someone not to worry, you say 괜찮아요.
 4. If you want to say everything is okay, you say 괜찮아요.

How to say this in past tense and future tense?

 Past tense: 괜찮았어요 [gwaen-cha-na-sseo-yo]
 Future tense: 괜찮을 거예요 [gwaen-cha-neul geo-ye-yo]

Lessons.title: It's okay even if ...
pages:
아/어/여도 되다 [a/eo/yeo-do doe-da] = It's okay to ...

 We can use 아/어/여도 되다 [a/eo/yeo-do doe-da] to mean 'it's okay to do something'

 It's a combination of
 아/어/여 + 도 = even if
 되다 [doe-da] = can do / to function

 Let's see some example
 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 해도 되다 [hae-do doe-da]
 it is okay even if you do

 나중에 해도 돼요
 [na-jung-e hae-do dwae-yo]
 It's okay even if you do it later

먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹어도 되다 [meo-geo-do doe-da]
 it is okay even if you eat

 이거 먹어도 돼요
 [i-go meo-geo-do dwae-yo]
 It's okay even if you eat this

 쓰다 [sseuda-da] = to use
 써도 되다 [sseo-do doe-da]
 it is okay even if use

 그거 써도 돼요
 [geu-geo sseo-do dwae-yo]
 It's okay even if you use that

If you add 안 [an] + verb + 아/어/여도 되다 [-a/eo/yeo-do doe-da], it will mean 'it's okay even if you don't do'. For example

 나중에 안 해도 돼요
 [na-jung-e an hae-do dwae-yo]
 It's okay even if you don't do it later

 이거 안 먹어도 돼요
 [i-go an meo-geo-do dwae-yo]
 It's okay even if you don't eat this

 그거 안 써도 돼요
 [geu-geo an sseo-do dwae-yo]
 It's okay even if you don't use that

Lessons.title: Anything, anywhere, anyone
pages:
Anything, anywhere, anyone

 To express anything, anywhere, anyone, we use the word 아무 [a-mu] + 나 [na] /  도 [do]

 아무거나 [a-mu-geo-na] = anything
 거 comes from 것 [geot] means 'thing'

 아무데나 [a-mu-de-na] = anywhere
 데 [de] means 'place'

 아무나 [a-mu-na] = anyone

 We use 나 [na] to express positive sentence

 아무거나 좋아요
 [a-mu-geo-na jo-a-yo.]
 Anything is good.

아무데나 가자
 [a-mu-de-na ga-ja.]
 Lets go anywhere.

 아무나 올 수 있어요
 [a-mu-na ol su i-sseo-yo.]
 Anybody can come.

 We use 도 [do] to express negative sentence

 아무것도 안했는데
 [a-mu-geo-do an-haess-neun-de]
 I didn't do anything.

 Please note for thing, it's 아무것도 and not 아무거도

아무데도 못가
 [a-mu-de-do mot-ga.]
 Can't go anywhere.

 아무도 올 수 없어요
 [a-mu-do ol su eop-seo-yo.]
 Nobody can come.

 If you use 나 [na] in negative sentence, it will mean 'not just anybody/anywhere/anything'

 아무나 올 수 없어요
 [a-mu-na ol su eop-seo-yo.]
 Not everybody can come

 아무도 올 수 없어요
 [a-mu-do ol su eop-seo-yo.]
 Nobody can come.

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's revision day again!

Lessons.title: You shouldn't
pages:
(으)면 안 되다 [-(eu)myeon an doe-da] = You shouldn't

 In movie, you should hear a lot of 안 돼요 [an dwae-yo] right? Let's learn how it comes from.

 돼요 is the present tense of 되다. Previously we have learned 되다 [doe-da] = can do / to function / to possible.

안 + 되다 [an doe-da] means 'it can't be done/function/possible'. In previous month, we also learned (으)면 means 'if'.

 If combined (으)면 + 안 + 되다 you get 'it is not possible/can't function if .....' which naturally means 'you should not'

Verb ending consonant, we use 으면 안 돼요
 Verb ending vowel or ㄹ, we use 면 안 돼요

 Let's see some example

 팔다 [pal-da] = to sell
 팔면 안 돼요 [pal-myeon an dwae-yo.]
 should not sell

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가면 안 돼요 [ga-myeon an dwae-yo.]
 should not go

 말하다 [mal-ha-da] = to talk/tell
 말하면 안 돼요 [ma-ra-myeon an dwae-yo.]
 should not talk/tell

먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹으면 안 돼요 [meo-geum-myeon an dwae-yo]
 should not eat

 마시다 [ma-si-da] = to drink
 마시면 안 돼요 [ma-si-myeon an dwae-yo]
 should not drink

 앉다 [anj-da] = to sit
 앉으면 안 돼요 [an-jeu-myeon an dwae-yo]
 should not sit

 들어가다 [deul-eo-ga-da] = to go in
 들어가면 안 돼요 [deul-eo-ga-myeon an dwae-yo]
 should not go in

Lessons.title: Try
pages:
아/어/여 보다 [a/eo/yeo bo-da] = Try to do something

 보다 [bo-da] = to see. Verb + 아/어/여 보다  means do something and see what happens, which literally means 'try to do something'

 쓰다 [sseu-da] = to use
 써 보다 [sseo bo-da] = to try using
 그거 써 봐요 [geu-geo sseo bwa-yo]
 Try using that

 먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹어 보다 [meo-geo bo-da] = to try eat
 이거 먹어 봐요 [meo-geo bwa-yo]
 Try eat this

하다 [ha-da] = to do
 해 보다 [hae bo-da] = to try do
 제가 먼저 해 볼게요
 [je-ga meon-jeo hae bol-ge-yo]
 I will try doing it first

 There's also expressions that are commonly used and already in the form of 아/어/여 보다. For example

 알아보다 [a-ra-bo-da]
 to look into something
 (there's no space between 아 보, so
 알아 보다 is wrong)

물어보다 [mu-reo-bo-da] = to ask
 물어 보다 [mu-reo bo-da] = to try asking
 For this there's space and no space version

 Sample sentence:

 제가 알아볼게요
 [je-ga a-ra-bol-ge-yo]
 I'll look into it

 영어로 물어봐요
 [yeon-geo-ro mul-eo-bwa-yo]
 Ask in English

Lessons.title: Among, between
pages:
To say among/between a list of choices, we use 중에서 [jung-e-seo] or in short form 중에 [jung-e].

 For example

 A하고 B 중에서 [A-ha-go B jung-e-seo]
 Between A and B
 하고 [ha-go] = and

 사과하고 바나나 중에서
 [sa-gwa-ha-go ba-na-na jung-e-seo]
 Between apple and banana
 바나나 [ba-na-na] = banana

 이 사 명 중에서
 [i sa myeong jung-e-seo]
 Among this four people
As 중에서 means among/between, you can't use this to describe location, such as 'I am at between the bank and the pharmacy'

 To describe location, we use 사이에 [sa-i-e]

 은행하고 약국 사이에 있어요
 [eun-haeng-ha-go yak-guk sa-i-e i-sseo-yo]
 I at between the bank and pharmacy

 은행은 학교하고 약국 사이에 있어요. [eun-haeng-eun hak-gyo-ha-go yak-guk sa-i-e i-sseo-yo.]
 The bank is in between the school and pharmacy

To express among a group of people, such as famous among friends, we use 사이에서 [sa-i-e-so]

 친구들 사이에서 인기가 많아요.
 [chin-gu-deul sa-i-e-seo in-gi-ga ma-na-yo.]
 He is popular among friends

Lessons.title: Frequency
pages:
Today we will look into how to describe frequency.

 자주 [ja-ju] = often
 가끔 [ga-kkeum] = sometimes
 거의 [geo-ui] = almost not at all

 별로 [byeol-lo] = seldom, rarely
 전혀 [jeon-hyeo] = not at all

 항상 [hang-sang] = always (mostly used in writing)
 맨날 [maen-nal] = all the time, always, everyday (mostly used in speaking)

 Usually, these words are used before verb. However, you can also use this after the verb. For example:-

가끔 도서관에 가요
 [ga-kkeum do-seo-gwan-e ga-yo]
 Sometimes I go to library

 도서관에 가끔 가요
 [do-seo-gwan-e ga-kkeum ga-yo]
 Sometimes I go to library (emphasize more on 'sometimes')

 항상 영화 봐요.
 [hang-sang yeong-hwa bwa-yo]
 I always watch movie.

 영화 항상 봐요.
 [yeong-hwa hang-sang bwa-yo]
 I always watch movie. (emphasize more on 'sometimes')

친구들을 거의 못 만나요.
 [chin-gu-deu-reul geo-ui mot man-na-yo.]
 I almost didn't meet my friend.

 자주 추천
 [ja-ju chu-cheon]
 Often recommended.

 학교에 맨날 가요
 [hak-gyo-e maen-nal ga-yo]
 I always(everyday) go to school.

Lessons.title: Spacing
pages:
Spacing in Korean. 띄어쓰기 [ttieosseugi]

 If you have tried 'Memory Attack' feature, you will surely having a hard time in spacing initially. Today, let's learn about spacing.

 Generally, you should keep these 3 things in mind.

 1. Korean Markers (particle)
 Basically, each word in Korean should stand alone. However, markers should be attached to the word. For example:-

 서울에 살아요
 [seo-ul-e sa-layo]
 I live in Seoul
 Noticed that 에 is attached to the word and so does the tenses 아요

저는 한국어를 공부해요
 [jeo-neun han-gu-geo-leul gong-bu-hae-yo]
 I study Korean
 Noticed that 는, 를 is attached to the word and so does the tenses 해요

 Spacing can be important as incorrect spacing will lead to wrong meaning. For example:-

 친구가 죽을 먹어요
 [chin-gu-ga ju-geul meo-geo-yo]
 My friend is eating rice soup

 친구 가죽을 먹어요
 [chin-gu ga-ju-geul meo-geo-yo]
 My friend is eating leather

2. Names in Korean
 Sometimes, Korean family name is written separately by space

 김 미나 [kim mi-na]
 Kim is family name. Last name is Mina

 3. Numbers
 There's space after 10 thousands 만 [man]. For example

 오십만 오백 [o-sip-man o-baek]
 50,500

 Of course there's alot more spacing rules, that even Korean themselves got confused. But these are the commons guideline for you.

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Revision day again!

Lessons.title: Less
pages:
덜 [deol] = less
 As you have learned, 더 [deo] = more. To say less, we use 덜 [deol] = less.

 덜 먹다 [deol meok-da] = to eat less
 덜 덥다 [deol deob-da] = to be less hot
 덜 빠르다 [deol ppa-leu-da] = to be less fast
 덜 비싸다 [deol bi-ssa-da] = to be less expensive

 어제보다 덜 더워요
 [eo-je-bo-da deol deo-wo-yo.]
 It's less hot than yesterday.

 여기에 덜 사야 돼요
 [yeo-gi-e deol sa-ya dwae-yo]
 You should buy less here

Lessons.title: Best / Most
pages:
제일 [je-il] / 가장 [ga-jang] = best / most

 We use 제일 [je-il] or 가장 [ga-jang] to describe best / most.

 제일 예뻐요
 [je-il ye-ppeo-yo]
 most pretty

 제일 비싸요
 [je-il bi-ssa-yo]
 most expensive

 가장 더워요
 [ga-jang deo-wo-yo]
 most hot

 가장 좋아요
 [ga-jang jo-a-yo]
 most good , best

제일은행
 [je-il-eun-haeng]
 best bank

 제일학교
 [je-il-hag-gyo]
 best school

 내가 제일 잘 나가
 [nae-ga je-il jal na-ga]
 I am the best

 엄마가 제일 예뻐요
 [eom-ma-ga je-il jal na-ga]
 Mum is the prettiest

Lessons.title: Short form
pages:
Short form

 As you have encountered in movies or lyrics, there's alot of phrases that can be shorten for ease of pronounciation.

 저는 [jeo-neun] = 전 [jeon]
 I am

 나는 [na-neun] = 난 [nan]
 I am

 어제는 [eo-je-neun] = 어젠 [eo-jen]
 When

 이것은 [i-geo-seun] = 이건 [i-geon]
 this (thing)

 이거는 [i-geo-neun] = 이건 [i-geon]
 this (thing)

Let's see some example sentences

 전 윤아예요.
 [jeon yun-a-ye-yo.]
 I'm Yuna.

 이건 뭐예요?.
 [i-geon mwo-ye-yo?]
 What is this?

 어젠 한국에 가요?.
 [eo-jen han-gug-ge ga-yo?]
 When you go to Korea?

Lessons.title: Grammar - Verb to Noun (Future tense)
pages:
Previously on Month 3 Lesson 15, have learned how to turn verb into noun. To refresh that lesson:-

 We use 는 것 [neun geot] to change verb into noun

 By changing verb into noun, it can mean
 1. the act of doing something
 2. the thing you doing

 For example:-
 보다 [bo-da] = to see
 보는 것 [bo-neun geot] = the act of seeing, the thing you see

How to do this in future tense? We use the form

 (으)ㄹ + noun

 보다 [bo-da] = to see
 보는 것 [bo-neun geot] = the act of seeing, the thing you see (present tense)
 볼 것 [bol geot] = something to be seen (future tense)
 볼 영화 [bol yeong-hwa] = movie to be seen

 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat
 먹는 것 [meok-neun geot] = the act of eating, the thing you eat (present tense)
 먹을 것 [meo-geul geot] = something to be eaten (future tense)

공부하다 [gong-bu-ha-da] = to study
 공부하는 것 [gong-bu-ha-neun geot] = the act of studying, the thing you study
 공부할 것 [gong-bu-hal geot] = something to be studied

 Let's see example sentence for better understanding

 Present tense
 제가 보는 영화예요
 [je-ga bo-neun yeong-hwa-ye-yo]
 It's a movie that I am seeing

 Future tense
 제가 볼 영화예요
 [je-ga bol yeong-hwa-ye-yo]
 It's a movie that I will be seeing

Present tense
 요즘 공부하는 한국어예요
 [yo-jeum gong-bu-ha-neun han-gu-geo-ye-yo]
 It's Korean language that I am studying recently

 Future tense
 내일 공부할 한국어예요
 [nae-il gong-bu-hal han-gu-geo-ye-yo]
 It's Korean language that I am studying tomorrow

Lessons.title: Grammar - Verb to Noun (Past tense)
pages:
To turn verb into noun in past tense, we use

 (으)ㄴ + noun

 보다 [bo-da] = to see
 본 [bon] = seen

 먹다 [meok-da] = to eat
 먹은 [meog-eun] = eaten

 공부하다 [gong-bu-ha-da] = to study
 공부한 [gong-bu-han] = studied

Let's see example sentence for better understanding

 Present tense
 제가 보는 영화예요
 [je-ga bo-neun yeong-hwa-ye-yo]
 It's a movie that I am seeing

 Future tense
 제가 볼 영화예요
 [je-ga bol yeong-hwa-ye-yo]
 It's a movie that I will be seeing

 Past tense
 제가 본 영화예요
 [je-ga bon yeong-hwa-ye-yo]
 It's a movie that I had seen

Present tense
 요즘 공부하는 한국어예요
 [yo-jeum gong-bu-ha-neun han-gu-geo-ye-yo]
 It's Korean language that I am studying recently

 Future tense
 내일 공부할 한국어예요
 [nae-il gong-bu-hal han-gu-geo-ye-yo]
 It's Korean language that I am studying tomorrow

 Past tense
 어제 공부한 한국어예요
 [eo-je gong-bu-han han-gu-geo-ye-yo]
 It's Korean language that I had studied yesterday

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's time to revise what you have learned

Lessons.title: Exception 르
pages:
Let's refresh how to create present tense.

 If the verb end with ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o], we joined with 아요 [a-yo].

 If the verb is NOT end with ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o], we joined with 어요 [eo-yo].

 If verb is 하 [ha], we joined with 여요 [yeo-yo]. For example

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] = to be pretty
 예쁘 + 어요 = 예뻐요 [ye-ppeo-yo] = pretty

 빠르다 [ppa-leu-da] = to be fast
 빠르 + 아요 = 빨라요 [ppa-la-yo] = fast

 But why 빠르 + 아요 and not 어요 since it's NOT end with ㅏ[a] or ㅗ [o]?

This is one of the many exceptions words. For 르, we remove 르 and add ㄹ at the end of previous vowel and add another ㄹ before the verb ending

 Thus from 빠르 will become 빨ㄹ + 아요 (because 빠 end with ㅏ[a]) = 빨라요

 More examples:-
 고르다 [go-reu-da] = to pick
 골ㄹ + 아요 = 골라요 [gol-la-yo] = pick

 모르다 [mo-reu-da] = not to know
 몰ㄹ + 아요 = 몰라요 [mol-la-yo] = don't know

자르다 [ja-reu-da] = to cut
 잘ㄹ + 아요 = 잘라요 [jal-la-yo] = cut

 기르다 [gi-reu-da] = to grow
 길ㄹ + 어요 = 길러요 [gil-leo-yo] = grow

Lessons.title: Much more / much less
pages:
훨씬 [hwol-ssin] = much more / much less

 You have learned more = 더 [deo]. To say much more, we use 훨씬 더 [hwol-ssin deo] or just 훨씬 [hwol-ssin]

 쉽다 [swib-da] = to be easy
 더 쉽다 [deo swib-da]
 to be more easy
 훨씬 더 쉽다 [hwol-ssin deo swib-da]
 to be much more easy

 비싸다 [bi-ssa-da] = to be expensive
 더 비싸다 [deo bi-ssa-da]
 to be more expensive
 훨씬 더 비싸다 [hwol-ssin deo bi-ssa-da]
 to be much more expensive
영어보다 한국어가 훨씬 쉬워요
 [yeong-eo-bo-da han-gu-geo-ga hwol-ssin swi-wo-yo]
 English is much more easier than Korean

 이게 훨씬 재미있어요
 [i-ge hwol-ssin jae-mi-iss-eo-yo]
 This is much more interesting

 이 사과가 훨씬 비싸요
 [i sa-gwa-ga hwol-ssin bi-ssa-yo]
 This apple is much more expensive
However to say much less you can't only use 훨씬 [hwol-ssin]. You need to use 훨씬 덜 [hwol-ssin deol].

 Remember 덜 [deol] = less?

 이 사과가 훨씬 덜 비싸요
 [i sa-gwa-ga hwol-ssin deol bi-ssa-yo]
 This apple is much less expensive

 이게 훨씬 덜 재미있어요
 [i-ge hwol-ssin deol jae-mi-iss-eo-yo]
 This is much less interesting

Lessons.title: 'Not'
pages:
부/불 [bul /bu] = 'not'

 부/불 [bul /bu] literally means 'not', and there's alot of words that comes with 부/불

 불 (not) + 편 (convenient) =
 불편 [bul-pyeon] =
 inconvenient

 불 (not) + 균형 (balance) =
 불균형 [bul-gyun-hyeong] =
 imbalance

 불 (not) + 안 (comfortable) =
 불안 [bul-an] =
 anxious

 불 (not) + 완전 (complete) =
 불완전 [bul-wan-jeon] =
 incomplete

부 (not) + 주의 (attention) =
 부주의 [bu-ju-ui] =
 unnoticed

 부 (not) + 적절 (proper) =
 부적절 [bu-jeog-jeol] =
 inappropriate

 부 (not) + 정확 (correct) =
 부정확 [bu-jeong-hwag] =
 incorrect

 부 (not) + 당 (right) =
 부당 [bu-dang] =
 unjust

Lessons.title: End up doing
pages:
To describe 'eventually / end up doing something' we use the form

 Verb + 게 되다 [ge doe-da]

 게 [ge] = in such a way that
 되다 [doe-da] = to become

 When combined, it become 'things happen in such a way when someone do something', which means:-
 1. eventually/end up doing something
 2. don't plan/want to, but also end up doing it

 Let's see some example
 보다 = to see
 보게 되다 = eventually/end up see

먹다 = to eat
 먹게 되다 = eventually/end up eat

 알다 = to know
