 알게 되다 = eventually/end up know

 하다 = to do
 하게 되다 = eventually/end up do

 You can use present, past, and future tense as well. Just change the tenses on 되다

Present tense
 보게 돼요 [bo-ge dwae-yo]
 먹게 돼요 [meok-ge dwae-yo]
 알게 돼요 [al-ge dwae-yo]
 하게 돼요 [ha-ge dwae-yo]

 Past tense
 보게 됐어요 [bo-ge dwae-sseo-yo]
 먹게 됐어요 [meok-ge dwae-sseo-yo]
 알게 됐어요 [al-ge dwae-sseo-yo]
 하게 됐어요 [ha-ge dwae-sseo-yo]

 Future tense
 보게 될 거예요 [bo-ge doel geo-ye-yo]
 먹게 될 거예요 [meok-ge doel geo-ye-yo]
 알게 될 거예요 [al-ge doel geo-ye-yo]
 하게 될 거예요 [ha-ge doel geo-ye-yo]

Let's see some example sentences

 어제 영화를 보게 됐어요
 [eo-je yeong-hwa-reul bo-ge dwae-sseo-yo]
 I didn't plan to, but I ended up watching movie yesterday

 나중에 알게 될 거예요
 [na-jung-e al-ge doel geo-ye-yo]
 You will eventually know later

 다 사게 될 거예요
 [da sa-ge doel geo-ye-yo]
 You will eventually buy everything

 이거 맛없어요. 그런데 먹게 돼요
 [i-geo mad-eop-seo-yo. geu-reon-de meok-ge dwae-yo]
 This is not tasty but I end up eating it

Lessons.title: To become
pages:
아/어/여지다 [a/eo/yeo-ji-da] = To become
 In order to describe 'to be come something', we use the form

 Verb + 아/어/여지다 [a/eo/yeo-ji-da]

 빠르다 [ppa-leu-da] = to be fast
 빠르 + 아지다 = 빨라지다 [ppa-leu-ji-da]
 to become fast
 Why it's 아지다 and not 어지다? Check out Month 4 Lesson 25

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] = to be pretty
 예쁘 + 어지다 = 예뻐지다 [ye-ppeo-ji-da]
 to become pretty

 재미있다 [jae-mi-it-da] = to be interesting
 재미있 + 어지다 = 재미있어지다
 [jae-mi-i-sseo-ji-da]
 to become interesting

이상하다 [i-sang-ha-da] = to be strange
 이상하 + 여지다 = 이상해지다
 [i-sang-hae-ji-da]
 to become strange

 After making 'to become' phrase, you can join it with present, past, future tense as usual.

 Let's see some example sentence

 저 자동차가 빨라졌어요
 [jeo ja-dong-cha-ga ppal-la-jyeo-sseo-yo]
 That car had become fast

 미나가 재미있어졌어요
 [mi-na-ga jae-mi-i-sseo-jyeo-sseo-yo]
 Mina had become interesting

다음주 다시 추워질 거예요
 [da-eum-ju da-si chu-wo-jil geo-ye-yo]
 Next week will become cold again

 물이 따뜻해졌어요
 [mul-i tta-tteu-tae-jyeo-sseo-yo]
 Water had become warm

Lessons.title: Exam
pages: Congratulations. You have completed the 4th month course and it's time to take an exam!

Lessons.title: Venue / Location
pages:
장 [jang] literally means venue/location. There's alot of words that has the word 장 and maybe some those you have already encountered in previous lessons.

 수영장 [su-yeong-jang] = swimming pool
 시장 [si-jang] = market
 주차장 [ju-cha-jang] = parking lot
 운동장 [un-dong-jang] = playground
 장소 [jang-so] = venue
 예식장 [ye-sig-jang] = wedding hall
 장면 [jang-myeon] = scene
 목장 [mog-jang] = farm

Lessons.title: I think
pages:
At Month 3 lesson 11, you have learned 같아요 [ga-ta-yo] = to be the same/similar.

 Then at Month 4 lesson 22, 23, you have learned how to turn verb into noun using

 Present tense
 는 것
 Past tense
 (으)ㄴ 것
 Future tense
 (으)ㄹ 것

 By combining these two structures

 Turn verb into noun + 같아요, it will mean 'I think ...'

For example
 먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹는 것 같다 [meog-neun geot ga-ta]
 the act of eating, the thing you eat (present tense) + I think

 먹을 것 같다 [meo-geul geot ga-ta]
 something to be eaten (future tense) + I think

 먹은 것 같다 [meog-eun geot ga-ta]
 eaten (past tense) + I think

 Let's see some example sentence
 미나는 먹는 것 같아요
 [mi-na-neun meog-neun geot ga-ta-yo]
 I think Mina is eating

내일 회의를 할 것 같아요
 [nae-il hoe-ui-leul hal geot ga-ta-yo]
 Tomorrow, I think will have meeting

 나중에 비 올 것 같아요
 [na-jung-e bi ol geot ga-ta-yo]
 I think will rain later

 이게 제일 좋은 것 같아요
 [i-ge je-il jo-eun geot ga-ta-yo]
 I think this is the most good / best

Lessons.title: Keep up the good work
pages:
수고하세요 [su-go-ha-se-yo] = Keep up the good work

 If you watched Korean movies, you most probably come across 수고하세요 [su-go-ha-se-yo] alot. 수고 actually means hard work or effort. As you have learned in previous lessons, 하세요 means please do.

 So when combined, it literally means 'please continue the hard work'. However, it's not really that meaning. When you say 수고하세요 to someone, it actually means you want to show your appreciation and support of their hardwork.

Please note that you can't say this to someone much older than you. It will appear as rude.
 You can also say 수고해요 [su-go-hae-yo] or 수고해 [su-go-hae] if someone is very close to you or younger than you.

 수고하셨습니다 [su-go-ha-syeot-sseum-ni-da] = You made alot of effort doing this

 If you say 수고하셨습니다 [su-go-ha-syeot-sseum-ni-da] to someone who just finished the work, it means 'Congratulations on finishing it'

 You can also say 수고했어요 [su-go-hae-sseo-yo] if someone is very close to you or younger than you.

Lessons.title: Almost did
pages:
(으)ㄹ 뻔했다 [eu/l ppeon-haess-da] = Almost did

 To say 'almost did something' we use

 Verb + (으)ㄹ 뻔했다

 뻔 = nearly getting into a situation where something happens

 먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹을 뻔했어요
 [meo-geul ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 almost eat

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 할 뻔했어요
 [hal ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 almost did

사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 살 뻔했어요
 [sal ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 almost bought

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 갈 뻔했어요
 [gal ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 almost went

 죽다 [juk-da] = to die
 죽을 뻔했어요
 [ju-geul ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 almost died
Let's see some example sentence

 너무 추워서 죽을 뻔했어요
 [neo-mu chu-wo-seo jug-eul ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 It was so cold, I almost died

 사기꾼의 말을 믿을 뻔했어요
 [sa-gi-ggu-neui ma-reul mi-deul ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 I almost believe the con artist

 돈을 잃을 뻔했어요
 [do-neul ppeon-hae-sseo-yo]
 I almost lost money

Lessons.title: As soon as
pages:
To say 'as soon as' you do something, we use 자마자 [ja-ma-ja]. The structure is

 Verb + 자마자 [ja-ma-ja]

 Let's see example

 끝나다 [kkeut-na-da] = to finish
 끝나자마자 [kkeut-na-ja-ma-ja]
 as soon as it finish

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가자마자 [ga-ja-ma-ja]
 as soon as you/i went

사다 [sa-da]
 사자마자 [sa-ja-ma-ja]
 as soon as you/i buy

 하다 [ha-da]
 하자마자 [ha-ja-ma-ja]
 as soon as you/i did

 Let's see some example sentences

 집에 오자마자 먹었어요
 [ji-be o-ja-ma-ja meo-geo-sseo-yo]
 As soon as I came home, I ate

 이거 보자마자 좋아했어요
 [i-go bo-ja-ma-ja joh-a-hae-sseo-yo]
 As soon as saw it, I like it

가자마자 일을 시작할 거예요
 [ga-ja-ma-ja i-reul si-jak-hal geo-ye-yo]
 As soon as I went there, I will start working
 시작하다 = to start

 As you can see from the examples, the tenses is shown at the end of the sentence.

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Let's revise what we have leared

Lessons.title: Writing / Letter
pages:
문 [mun] is related to writing or letter. Let's see some examples of words that has 문 [mun]

 문서 [mun-seo] = document
 문장 [mun-jang] = sentence
 문자 [mun-ja] = character / text
 문학 [mun-hak] = literature
 문법 [mun-beop] = grammar
 문화 [mun-hwa] = culture
 문화재 [mun-hwa-jae] = cultural properties
 주문 [ju-mun] = order
 논문 [non-mun] = thesis

Lessons.title: I guess / assume
pages:
In month 5 lesson 2, we have learned how to say 'I think'. In this lesson, we will learn how to say 'I assume, I guess'. There's alot of rules to be remember in this lesson.

 For present tense, we use
 Verb + 나 보다 [na bo-da]

 For past tense, we use
 Verb + 았/었/였 + 나 보다 [at/eot/yeot + na bo-da]

 Examples
 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 하나 봐요 [ha-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they do (present tense)
 했나 봐요 [haet-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they did (past tense)

모르다 [mo-reu-da] = to not know
 모르나 봐요 [mo-reu-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they don't know (present tense)

 몰랐나 봐요 [mol-lat-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they didn't know (past tense)

 없다 [eop-da] = to not exists
 없나 봐요 [eop-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they is not there (present tense)

 없었나 봐요 [eop-seot-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they was not there (past tense)

사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 사나 봐요 [sa-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they buy it (present tense)

 샀나 봐요 [sat-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they bought (past tense)

 This structure usually used when you are talking about others. If you use this to talk about yourself, you are assuming yourself as the third person on doing that.

For descriptive verb, we use the structure

 Verb + (으)ㄴ가 봐요 (for present tense)
 Verb + 았/었/였나 봐요 (for past tense)

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] = to be pretty
 예쁜가 봐요 [ye-ppeun-ga bwa-yo]
 I guess it is pretty (present tense)

 예뻤나 봐요 [ye-ppeot-na bwa-yo]
 I guess it was pretty (past tense)

 작다 [jak-da] = to be small
 작은가 봐요 [jag-eun-ga bwa-yo]
 I guess it is small

 작았나 봐요 [jag-at-na bwa-yo]
 I guess it was small

많아다 [manh-a-da] = to be many
 많은가 봐요 [ma-neun-ga bwa-yo]
 I guess it is many

 많았나 봐요 [manh-at-na bwa-yo]
 I guess it was many

 If the descriptive verb contains 있다 [it-da] or 없다 [eop-da], we use the structure

 Verb + 나 봐요 [na bwa-yo]

 재미있다 [jae-mi-it-da]
 to be fun, to be interesting
 재미있나 봐요 [jae-mi-it-na bwa-yo]
 I guess it's fun

 재미있었나 봐요
 [jae-mi-it-seot-na-na bwa-yo]
 I guess it was fun

Let's see some example sentences

 미나는 아직 모르나 봐요
 [mi-na-neun a-jik mo-reu-na bwa-yo]
 I guess Mina still doesn’t know

 돈이 없나 봐요
 [don-i eob-na bwa-yo]
 I guess he/she/they don't have money

 눈이 오나 봐요
 [nu-ni o-na bwa-yo]
 I guess it's snowning

 돈이 많았나 봐요
 [don-i ma-nat-na bwa-yo]
 I guess there was a lot of money

Lessons.title: About to
pages:
In Korean, there's alot of ways to express future tense. Today we will learn another one. Let's review what we have learned so far.

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 할 거예요 [hal geo-ye-yo]
 I’m going to do (plain future tense)

 할게요 [hal-ge-yo] = I'm going to do (looking for someone's reaction)

 할래요 [hal-lae-yo] = I'm going to do (show determination to do)

Today we will learn

 Verb + (으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeo-go ha-da]

 We use this when:- 
 1. Something is about to happen
 2. Someone about to do something

 Let's see some examples

 오다 [o-da] = to come
 오려고 해요 [o-lyeo-go hae-yo]
 about to come

 울다 [ul-da] = to cry
 울려고 해요 [ul-lyeo-go hae-yo]
 about to cry

만나다 [man-na-da] = to meet
 만나려고 해요 [man-na-ryeo-go hae-yo]
 about to meet

 사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 사려고 해요 [sa-ryeo-go hae-yo]
 about to buy

 Let's see some example sentences

 친구가 울려고 해요
 [chin-gu-ga ul-lyeo-go hae-yo]
 My friend is about to cry

Lessons.title: To say 'this is ...'
pages:
To quote 'that it is ABC', we use the structure

 Nouns ending with consonant + 이라고 [i-ra-go]
 Nouns ending with vowel + 라고 [ra-go]
 For example: 

 사과 [sa-gwa] = apple
 사과라고 [sa-gwa-ra-go] = that it is apple

 Usually this is used along with
 말하다 [mal-ha-da] = to say
 대답하다 [dae-dab-ha-da] = to answer
 or just 하다 [ha-da] = to say (normally it mean to do, but in this context it's to say)

사과라고 말하다
 [sa-gwa-ra-go ma-ra-da]
 To say 'that it is apple'

 안녕이라고 말하다
 [an-nyeong-i-ra-go ma-ra-da]
 To say '안녕'

 이거라고 하다
 [i-geo-ra-go ha-da]
 To say that 'this is this'

 Let's see some example sentence for better understanding

 중국 사람이라고 했어요
 [jung-guk sa-ra-mi-ra-go hae-sseo-yo]
 He/she/they said he/she/they is a Chinese person

제가 제일이라고 들었어요
 [je-ga je-il-i-ra-go deu-reo-sseo-yo.]
 I heard he/she/they say I am the best

 여기가 도서관이라고 말해요
 [yeo-gi-ga do-seo-gwan-i-ra-go ma-rae-yo]
 He/she/they say that this is the library

 뭐라고 말했어요?
 [mwo-ra-go ma-rae-sseo-yo?]
 What did you say?

Lessons.title: While doing A, then B happen
pages:
Today we will learn how to describe a gradual transition from action A to action B. For example

 I was studying and then I fell asleep
 I was exercising and got injured

 To join this actions, we use the structure

 Verb + 다가 [da-ga]

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가다가 [ga-da-ga]

 오다 [o-da] = to come
 오다가 [o-da-ga]

 먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹다가 [meog-da-ga]

Let's see some example sentences

 집에 오다가 선생님을 만났어요
 [ji-be o-da-ga seon-saeng-nim-eul man-na-sseo-yo]
 While coming home, I met my teacher

 여행을 하다가 아팠어요
 [yeo-haeng-eul ha-da-ga a-pass-eo-yo]
 While going vacation, I got sick

 밥 먹다가 친구를 왔어요
 [bap meok-da-ga chin-gu-reul wa-sseo-yo]
 I was eating and my friend came

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's revision day again. Let's revise!

Lessons.title: Because of A, then B happen
pages:
Today we will learn another way to link sentences. This structure is to link because of A, then B happen

 Verb reason A + (으)니까 [(eu)-ni-kka]  + Verb result B

 If verb end with consonant we add 으니까 [(eu)ni-kka]

 If verb end with vowel we add 니까 [ni-kka]
Let's see examples for easier understanding

 Reason
 지금 바빠요
 [ji-geum ba-ppa-yo]
 I'm busy now

 Result
 나중에 먹을 거예요
 [na-jung-e meog-eul geo-ye-yo]
 I will eat later

 지금 바쁘니까 나중에 먹을 거예요
 [ji-geum ba-ppeu-ni-kka na-jung-e meog-eul geo-ye-yo]
 I'm busy now, so I will eat later

Reason
 지금 피곤해요
 [ji-geum pi-gon-hae-yo]
 I'm tired now

 Result
 나중에 전화해 주세요
 [na-jung-e jeon-hwa-hae ju-se-yo]
 Please call me later

 지금 피곤하니까 나중에 전화해 주세요
 [ji-geum pi-gon-ha-ni-kka na-jung-e jeon-hwa-hae ju-se-yo]
 I'm tired now, so please call me later

Besides joining sentences (reason/result), we can also use 으니까 to mark the ending when you are answering question

 이거 왜 먹었어요?
 [i-geo wae meo-geo-sseo-yo?]
 Why did you ate this?

 맛있으니까
 [mas-iss-eu-ni-kka]
 Because it is delicious

Have you heard of the music video 여자이니까 [yeo-ja-i-ni-kka]?

If we join with noun, and the noun end with consonant, we use 이니까 [i-ni-kka].

If it's not end with consonant, then you can use either 이니까 [i-ni-kka] or 니까 [ni-kka]

 여자이니까
 [yeo-ja-i-ni-kka]
 Because I'm a girl

 오늘 토요일이니까 내일 하세요
 [o-neul to-yo-il-i-ni-kka na-eil ha-se-yo]
 Today is Saturday so do it tomorrow

Lessons.title: End sentence with 다
pages:
(ㄴ/는)다

 Have you wondered why sometimes sentences ended with 다 [da] instead of 요 [yo]? For example people says

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] instead of 예뻐요 [yep-peo-yo] = pretty

 We use (ㄴ/는)다 to

 1. Show reaction when talking about something

 예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] = pretty! (show surprised or excitement)
 예뻐요 [yep-peo-yo] = pretty (statement)

2. Talk about regular activity
 매일 공부해야 한다
 [mae-il gong-bu-hae-ya han-da]
 You need to study everyday

 3. Talk about present activity as third person and expecting some reaction from the one listening
 저기 내 누나들 온다.
 [jeo-gi nae nu-na-deul on-da]
 There comes my sister

Lessons.title: Gathering
pages:
Let's learn more vocabulary today.
 회 [hoe] is related to 'gathering'. For examples:

 회의 [hoe-ui] = meeting
 회의실 [hoe-ui-sil] = meeting room
 회사 [hoe-sa] = company
 회사원 [hoe-sa-won] = employee
 회원 [hoe-won] = member
 회비 [hoe-bi] = membership fee
 회계 [hoe-gyeo] = accounting
 동호회 [dong-ho-hoe] = club
 회화 [hoe-hwo] = conversation
 사회 [sa-hoe] = society
 국회 [guk-hoe] = parliamentary meeting
 교회 [gyo-hoe] = church
 대회 [dae-hoe] = competition

Lessons.title: Any choice is fine
pages:
Today we will learn about (이)라도 [(i)-ra-do]. We use (이)라도 when

 1. Any choice is fine
 Used on 아무 [a-mu] (any), 누구 [nu-gu] (who), 어디 [eo-di] (where), 언제 [eon-je] (when), 어느 [eo-neu] (which)

 누구라도 [nu-g-ra-do]
 Anyone is fine

 언제라도 [eon-je-ra-do]
 Anytime is fine

 어디라도 갈 수 있어요 [eo-di-ra-do gal su i-sseo-yo]
 I can go anywhere (Any location is fine)

2. Not the best out of all choices
 커피라도 [keo-pi-ra-do]
 coffee (but not the best of all choices)

 사과라도 [sa-gwa-ra-do]
 apple (but not the best of all choices)

 영화라도 볼래요?
 [yeong-hwa-ra-do bol-lae-yo?]
 Maybe we can watch movie? (you suggest watching movie but it's not the best activity, but it's better than doing nothing)

 이거라도 주세요
 [i-geo-ra-do ju-se-yo]
 Give me this (If you don't have anything better)


3. Show suspicion
 파티라도 났어요?
 [pa-ti-ra-do na-sseo-yo?]
 You had a party? (You suspect the person had a party)

 For words ending with consonant, we use 이라도 [i-ra-do]

 For words ending with vowel, we use 라도 [ra-do]

Lessons.title: Instead of
pages:
대신에 [dae-sin-e] = Instead of
 To say 'instead of', we use 대신에 [dae-sin-e]

대신 [dae-sin] comes from the verb 대신하다 [dae-sin-ha-da] = to replace

 If join with noun, we use 대신에 [dae-sin-e]

 저거 대신에
 [jeo-geo dae-si-ne]
 Instead of that

 영화 대신에
 [yeong-hwa dae-si-ne]
 Instead of movie

If join with verb, we use
 Verb + 는 + 대신에

 사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 사는 대신에 [sa-neun dae-sin-e]
 instead of buying

 가다 [ga-da] = to buy
 가는 대신에 [ga-neun dae-sin-e]
 instead of going

 Let's see some example sentence

 카메라 대신에 컴퓨터를 샀어요
 [ka-me-ra dae-si-ne keom-pyu-teo-reul sa-sseo-yo]
 I bought computer instead of camera

저 대신에 엄마가 올 거예요
 [jeo dae-si-ne eom-ma-ga ol geo-ye-yo]
 My mother will come instead of me

 친구를 기다리는 대신에 혼자 갔어요
 [chin-gu-leul gi-da-li-neun dae-sin-e hon-ja gass-eo-yo]
 Instead of waiting for my friend I went alone

 여행을 가는 대신에 컴퓨터 게임을 했어요
 [yeo-haeng-eul ga-neun dae-si-ne keom-pyu-teo ge-im-eul hae-sseo-yo]
 Instead of travelling, I played computer games

Besides meaning 'instead of', if you use 대신에 between verbs, it can also means 'in return'. For example:-

 이번에는 제가 도와 줄게요. 대신에, 내일 일찍 와야 돼요
 [i-beon-e-neun je-ga do-wa jul-ge-yo. dae-si-ne, nae-il il-jjik wa-ya dwae-yo]
 I will help you this time. But in return, you have to be here early tomorrow

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: It's revision day again!

Lessons.title: Quote someone tell someone to do ...
pages:
In Month 5 Lesson 10, you have learned about 라고 [ra-go]. Today, we will learn about (으)라고 [(eu)-ra-go]

 We use the following to talk about someone tell someone to do something (you as the narrative). 

 Verb + (으)라고 [(eu)-ra-go] +  하다 [ha-da]

 If verb ending with consonant, we use 으라고 [eu-ra-go]
 If verb ending with vowel, we use 라고 [ra-go]
Let's see example
 보다 [bo-da] = to watch
 보라고 하다 [bo-ra-go ha-da]
 to tell someone to look (you as the narative)

 친구가 영화를 보라고 해요
 [chin-gu-ga yeong-hwa-reul bo-la-go hae-yo]
 My friend tell me to watch movie

 공부하다 [gong-bu-ha-da] = to study
 공부하라고 하다 [gong-bu-ha-ra-go ha-da]
 to tell someone to study
 친구가 공부하라고 해요 [chin-gu-ga gong-bu-ha-ra-go hae-yo]
 My friend tell me to study

가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가라고 하다 [ga-ra-go ha-da]
 to tell someone to go

 누가 가라고 했어요?
 [nu-ga ga-ra-go haess-o-yo?]
 Who told me/he/she/them to go?

 오다 [o-da] = to come
 오라고 하다 [o-ra-go ha-da]
 to tell someone to come

 친구가 우리 오라고 했어요
 [chin-gu-ga u-ri o-ra-go haess-o-yo]
 My friend told us to come

Lessons.title: Short form
pages:
In the first month, you have learned object marker is (을/를). In spoken Korean, we can shorten 를 by joining ㄹ to the previous word

 Here's some of the common words that's shorten when we speak

 저 [jeo] = me
 저를 [jeo-reul] can be shorten to 절 [jeol]

 여기 [yeo-gi] = here
 여기를 [yeo-gi-reul] ---shorten--> 여길 [yeo-gil]

 뭐 [mwo] = what
 뭐를 [mwo-reul] ---shorten--> 뭘 [mwol]

이거 [i-geo] = what
 이거를 [i-geo-reul] ---shorten--> 이걸 [i-geol]

 Let's see some examples

 누가 절 불렀어요?
 [nu-ga jeol bul-leo-sseo-yo?]
 Who called me?

 뭘 도와 드릴까요?
 [mwol do-wa deu-lil-kka-yo?]
 What can I do for you?

 이걸 누구한테 줘야 돼요?
 [i-geol nu-gu-han-te jwo-ya dwae-yo?]
 Whom should I give this to?

Lessons.title: I assume (pretty sure will happen)
pages:
In month 5 lesson 2, we learned about (으)ㄹ 것 같다 [(eu/r) geot ga-ta] to express I think something happen. In that context, you are pretty sure what you think is correct.

If you are not so sure, and just assume based on what you saw, we use

 (으)려나 보다 [(eu)-ryeo-na bo-da]

 This actually comes from
 (으)려고 하다 (Month 5 lesson 9) + 나 보다 (Month 5 lesson 8) = (으)려고 하나 보다 [(eu)-ryeo-go ha-na bo-da]

For verb ending with a vowel, we use 려나 보다 [ryeo-na bo-da]

 For verb ending with a consonant, we use 으려나 보다 [eu-ryeo-na bo-da]

 Let's see some examples

 닫다 [dat-da] = to close
 닫으려나 보다
 [da-deu-ryeo-na bo-da]
 I assume will close / It looks it will close

 시작하다 [si-jak-ha-da] = to start
 시작하려나 보다
 [si-jak-ha-ryeo-na bo-da]
 I assume will start / It looks it will start
가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가려나 보다
 [ga-ryeo-na bo-da]
 I assume will go / It looks will go

 춥다 [chub-da] = to be cold
 추우려나 보다
 [chu-u-ryeo-na bo-da]
 I assume will be cold / It looks like will be cold

 Let's see some example sentences

 나중에 시작하려나 봐요
 [na-jung-e si-ja-ka-ryeo-na bwa-yo]
 It looks like it's going to start later

도서관에 가려나 봐요
 [do-seo-gwan-e ga-ryeo-na bwa-yo]
 It looks like he/she will go to library

 날씨가 추우려나 봐요.
 [nal-ssi-ga chu-u-ryeo-na bwa-yo]
 It looks like the weather will be cold

Lessons.title: Food / eating
pages:
Today we will learn words that has 식 [sik]. If the words has 식, it's usually related to food or eating

 For example

 식당 [sik-dang] = restaurant
 음식 [eum-sik] = food
 식사 [sik-sa] = meal
 식품 [sik-pum] = food products
 후식 [hu-sik] = dessert
 식탁 [sik-tak] = dining table
 시식 [si-sik] = food sampling
 간식 [gan-sik] = snack
 외식 [oe-sik] = to eat outside
 과식 [gwa-sik] = overeat

Lessons.title: This. Not that
pages:
In Month 3 Lesson 1 you have learned 지 마세요 [ji ma-se-yo] = Don't do something.

To review, this expression comes from 말다 [mal-da] = to stop doing

 In order to say 'not noun A but noun B', we say
 Noun A + 말고 + Noun B

 If you want to say 'not verb A but verb B', we say
 Verb A + 지 말고 + Verb B

 Let's see some examples
 빵 말고 커피 주세요
 [ppang mal-go keo-pi ju-se-yo]
 Please give me coffee, not bread

이거 말고 저거 주세요
 [i-geo mal-go jeo-geo ju-se-yo]
 Please give me that, not this

 늦지 말고 일찍 가세요
 [neut-ji mal-go il-jjik ga-se-yo]
 Don't be late and go early

 전화하지 말고 조금만 기다리세요
 [jeon-hwa-ha-ji mal-go jo-geum-man gi-da-li-se-yo]
 Don't call me but wait for me a while

Lessons.title: Revision
pages: Let's revise what we have learned.

Lessons.title: Rather / Abit
pages:
To describe something that is not so definitive (rather big, abit big), we use

 ㄴ/은/는 편이다 [n/eu/neun pyeo-ni-da]

 Action verb present tense
 Verb + 는 편이다
 Action verb past tense
 Verb + ㄴ/은 편이다

 Descriptive verb
 Verb ending with vowel + ㄴ 편이다
 Verb ending with consonant + 은 편이다

 Let's see some examples
 크다 [keu-da] = to be big
 커요 [keo-yo] = big
 큰 편이에요 [keun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 rather big / abit big
작다 [jag-da] = to be small
 작아요 [jag-a-yo] = small
 작은 편이에요 [jag-eun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 rather small / abit small

 바쁘다 [ba-ppeu-da] = to be busy
 바빠요 [ba-ppa-yo] = busy
 바쁜 편이에요 [ba-ppeun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 rather busy / abit busy

 오다 [o-da] = to come
 자주 와요 [ja-ju wa-yo] = frequent come
 자주 오는 편이에요
 [ja-ju o-neun pyeo-ni-e-yo]
 rather frequent come
빠르다 [ppa-leu-da] = to be fast
 빨라요 [ppal-la-yo] = fast
 빠른 편이에요 [ppa-leun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 rather fast

 Let's see some example sentences

 저도 도서관에 자주 가는 편이에요
 [jeo-do do-seo-gwan-e ja-ju ga-neun pyeo-ni-e-yo]
 I go library rather frequent too

 이거 큰 편이에요
 [i-geo keun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 This is rather big

 테니스를 잘 치는 편이에요
 [te-ni-seu-leul jal chi-neun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 I play tennis rather well

Lessons.title: As compared to
pages:
In Month 2 Lesson 22, you have learned 보다 [bo-da] is used to compare things. Another commonly used expression is

 에 비해서 [e bi-hae-seo]

 비 comes from the word 비교 which means comparison

 Let's see examples:

 어제에 비해서 바쁜 편이에요
 [o-je-e bi-hae-seo ba-ppeun pyeo-ni-e-yo]
 I'm rather busy as compared to yesterday

 저거에 비해서 비싼 편이에요
 [jeo-go-e bi-hae-seo bi-ssan pyeon-i-e-yo]
 It's rather expensive as compared to that

한국은 중국에 비해서 작은 편이에요
 [han-gug-eun jung-gug-e bi-hae-seo jag-eun pyeon-i-e-yo]
 Compared to China, Korea is rather small

 한국은 태국에 비해서 인터넷이 정말 빨라요
 [han-gug-eun tae-gug-e bi-hae-seo in-teo-net jeong-mal ppal-la-yo]
 Compared to Thailand, internet in Korea is really fast

qna.Compared to Thailand, internet in Korea: 한국은 태국에 비해서 인터넷이 정말 빨라요

options: 한국은 태국에 비해서 인터넷이 정말 빨라요

Lessons.title: True right?
pages:
To ask someone to agree with your or to correct someone, we use the expression

 잖아요 [ja-na-yo]

 Remember 지 않아요 [ji anh-a-yo] in Month 1 Lesson 25 which means 'to not'? 잖아요 [ja-na-yo] comes from this, but in this case, it's used to ask someone to agree with your or to correct them.

 Let's see examples:

 알다 [al-da] = to know
 알아요 [a-la-yo] = know
 알잖아요 [al-ja-na-yo] = Come on, you know right?
예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] = to be pretty
 예뻐요 [yep-peo-yo] = pretty
 예뻐잖아요 [yep-peo-ja-na-yo] = Come on, pretty right? / No it's not true. It's pretty

 춥다 [chup-da] = to be cold
 추워요 [chu-wo-yo] = cold
 춥잖아요 [chup-ja-na-yo] = You see right? It's cold. / No it's not true. It's cold.
 춥지 않아요 [chup-ji a-na-yo] = It is not cold.

 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 해요 [hae-yo] = do
 하잖아요 [ha-ja-na-yo] = You see right? I'm doing. / No it's not true. I do.
 하지 않아요 [ha-ja a-na-yo] = I don't do.

있다 [ha-da] = to have
 있어요 [iss-eo-yo] = has
 있잖아요 [it-ja-na-yo] = You know right? It has.

 Let's see some more example

 오늘 춥잖아요 [o-neul chup-ja-na-yo]
 Come on, today is cold, right?

 이거 예뻐잖아요 [i-geo yep-peo-ja-na-yo]
 Come on, this is pretty, right?

Lessons.title: To have no other choice but
pages:
Today, we will learn to say 'to have no other choice but'. We use the structure

 (으)ㄹ 수밖에 없다 [(eu)l su ba-kke eopda]

 If you break down the structure, you will have something you learned before

 (으)ㄹ 수 없다 [(eu)l su eop-da]
 cannot (Month 2 Lesson 17)
 밖에 + negative sentence = only

 When put together it literally means 'no other choice but'

 Let's see example
 하다 [ha-da] = to do
 할 수밖에 없다 [hal su-ba-kke eop-da]
 to have no other choice but to do

사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 살 수밖에 없다 [sal su-ba-kke eop-da]
 to have no other choice but to buy

 팔다 [pal-da] = to sell
 팔 수밖에 없다 [pal su-ba-kke eop-da]
 to have no other choice but to sell

 어렵다 [eo-lyeob-da] = to be difficult
 어려울 수밖에 없다
 [eo-lyeo-ul su-ba-kke eop-da]
 to have no other choice but be difficult

Let's see some example sentence

 이렇게 할 수밖에 없어요
 [i-reo-ke hal su-ba-kke eop-seo-yo]
 There's no other choice but to do it this way

 고기를 먹을 수밖에 없어요
 [go-gi-leul meog-eul su-ba-kke eop-seo-yo]
 There's no other choice but to eat meat

Lessons.title: In the middle of
pages:
To say 'in the middle of something' we use the structure

 Verb + 고 있는 중이다 [go it-neun jung-i-da]

 가다 [ga-da] = to go
 가고 있는 중이에요
 [ga-go it-neun jung-i-e-yo]
 In the middle of going / on the way

 먹다 [meog-da] = to eat
 먹고 있는 중이에요
 [meog-go it-neun jung-i-e-yo]
 In the middle of eating

공부하다 [gong-bu-ha-da] = to study
 공부하고 있는 중이에요
 [gong-bu-ha-go it-neun jung-i-e-yo]
 In the middle of studying

 사다 [sa-da] = to buy
 사고 있는 중이에요
 [sa-go it-neun jung-i-e-yo]
 In the middle of buying

 기다리다 [gi-da-ri-da] = to wait
 기다리고 있는 중이에요
 [gi-da-ri-go it-neun jung-i-e-yo]
 In the middle of waiting

Lessons.title: Exam
pages: You have learned alot. Let's conclude this month with exam!

qna.Compared to Thailand, internet in Korea: 한국은 태국에 비해서 인터넷이 정말 빨라요

options: 한국은 태국에 비해서 인터넷이 정말 빨라요

Hanguls:
If you are learning to read Korean (hangul) by romanization and memorizing, then you are learning it the wrong way. The romanization is just to aid you in reading.

 In this section, we will teach you how to read Hangul. Before we dive deep, we must understand the origin of Hangul.

 If you know the origin, then it's so much easier to read the Hangul. As quoted by the creator King Sejong, the fourth King of Chosun Dynasty who created Hangul:-

 A wise man can acquaint himself with them before the morning is over.
 A stupid man can learn them in the space of 10 days

So, we all know how to read abc. But why A sounds like A, B sounds like B? When does abc is created and by who? No idea right?

 Hangul is a really special writing system. It's recognised by UNESCO because it's the only language/writing system that is well documented on who is the creator, when it was created and why the principles of its creation are known.

 During the ancient times in Korea, people speak in Korean but there's no Hangul to represent it in writing. People use Chinese characters to represent the Korean sounds in writing.
As we all know, Chinese is a very difficult language to master because we need to memorize thousands of characters. Not all people have the knowledge of this.

 So, King Sejong decided to create a simple language/writing system so that the citizens able to express what they want in writing.

 And he really wanted it simple. He didn't want people to study years to understand how to write. He wanted people to learn it within days.

 So, he gathered a team of scholars. They work day and night and finally created Hangul. It's published in 1446.
Okay, enough of stories. Let's start to learn how to read. Just like in abc, Hangul has consonants and vowels. Let's look at consonants first.
Consonants consist of:-
    ㄱ - g                      ㄲ - kk
    ㄴ - n
    ㄷ - d                      ㄸ - tt
    ㄹ - r/l
    ㅁ - m
    ㅂ - b                      ㅃ - pp
    ㅅ - s                      ㅆ - ss
    ㅇ - no sound
    ㅈ - j                       ㅉ - jj
    ㅊ - ch
    ㅋ - k
    ㅌ - t
    ㅍ - p
    ㅎ - h

 Again, the romanization is just to aid you. There is no need to memorize the romanization. Under King Sejong times, there is no romanization right?
These consonants are shaped like that because it's shaped like your vocal organs (back of your tongue, tongue, lip, teeth, throat) when pronouncing. Consonants that have stronger sounds will have extra strokes.

 ㄱ (g)
 ㄱ (g) will sounds like when the back of your tongue stick with the top of your mouth, blocking the throat. Try move your tongue like the diagram below and push out a sound. Isn't it sounds like 'g' / something similar? (*** Off the background music on the main page if you have difficulty hearing)
From ㄱ, we can make another 2 kind of sounds by changing abit of tone while remaining the same organ structure like the diagram.

ㅋ - (k)  pronounce (a sound) with an exhalation of breath.
ㄲ - (kk) pronounce with some tension, sharpness

 So, you have learned how to speak ㄱ,ㅋ,ㄲ. Easy right? Instead of memorizing ㄱ = g, ㅋ = k, ㄲ = kk
ㄴ (n)
 ㄴ (n) will sounds like when the tip of your tongue touch your upper gum and you let out a sound. Just like the shape as diagram below and when you try to sound (n).
Again from ㄴ (n), we can make 4 types of other sounds.

ㄷ - (d)
ㅌ - (t) pronounce (a sound) with an exhalation of breath.
ㄸ - (tt) pronounce with some tension, sharpness
ㄹ - (r/l) will sound like your tongue moving/retracting backward, without touching anything and releasing a sound. Just like (r/l) in alphabet. Can you imagine this shape ㄹ within your mouth?
ㅁ (m)
 ㅁ - (m) will sounds like the shape of lips as diagram below, and pushing out a sound.
From ㅁ - (m), we can make 3 types of other sounds.

ㅂ - (b)
ㅍ - (p) pronounce (a sound) with an exhalation of breath.
ㅃ - (pp) pronounce with some tension, sharpness
ㅅ (s)
 ㅅ - (s) will sounds like upper teeths and lower teeths pressing each other and releasing sound.
From ㅅ (s), we can make 4 other sounds.

ㅈ - (j)
ㅊ - (ch) pronounce (a sound) with an exhalation of breath.
ㅆ - (ss) pronounce with some tension, sharpness
ㅉ - (jj) pronounce with some tension, sharpness
ㅇ (no sound / ng)
 Lastly, ㅇ take the shape of the throat. It can either be silent sound or (ng). We will learn more about this in later part of lesson.

 From ㅇ, we can extend this to ㅎ (h) pronounce (a sound) with an exhalation of breath.
There's actually name for consonants. In romanization, we say A is A, B is B. How to we call ㄱ, ㄴ, ㄷ, ㄹ...?

 ㄱ is called 기역 giyeok
 Please note, the front part of the sound is actually how to pronounce ㄱ
 ㄴ = 니은 nieun
 ㄷ = 디귿 dikeut
 ㄹ = 리을 rieul
 ㅁ = 미음 mieum
 ㅂ = 비읍 bieup
 ㅅ = 시옷 siot
 ㅇ = 이응 ieung
 ㅈ = 지읒 jieut
 ㅊ = 치읓 chieut
 ㅋ = 키읔 kieuk
 ㅌ = 티읕 tieut
 ㅍ = 피읖 pieup
 ㅎ = 히읗 hieuh
Then, we also have double consonants

 ㄲ = 쌍기역 ssanggieok
 ㄸ = 쌍디귿 ssangdikeut
 ㅃ = 쌍비읍 ssangbieup
 ㅆ = 쌍시옷 ssangsiot
 ㅉ = 쌍지읒 ssangjieut

 쌍 (ssang) means double
Vowels are based on philosophic concept. The basic vowels are derived from
 heaven(sky) = .
 earth(land) = __
 human = |

For vowels sounds, these sounds are all coming out from your throat without touching anything on the way out.

 There's positive vowel and negative vowel. Positive vowels are when the sun . is above or on the right. Positive sounds are light and bright.

 For example:- ㅏ ㅗ ㅑ ㅛ ㅐ ㅚ
Negative sounds are when the sun is below or on the left. Negative sounds are heavy and dull.

 For example:- ㅓ ㅜ ㅕ ㅠ ㅔ ㅟ

Since, these vowels are not the representations of your organs, you can only memorize these by remembering positive and negative sounds.
Alright, so we have learn all the consonants and vowels. Let's see how these consonants and vowels are combined to form a character.

 Character combination is based on the picture below
When you read, the sounds will come from 1. Consonant --> 2. Vowel --> 3. Final Consonant as of previous diagram.

 If ㅇ is in 1. position, there's no sound for ㅇ. If it's on 3. position, it will sound (ng).

 Let's review the most common phrase in Korea. 안녕하세요 [an-nyeong-ha-se-yo].

 For 안 we read from 1. Consonant --> 2. Vowel --> 3. Final Consonant. ㅇ is in 1. position, so there's no sound for ㅇ.
For 녕 we read from 1. Consonant --> 2. Vowel --> 3. Final Consonant. ㅇ is in 3. position, so ㅇ sounds (ng)
For 하 we read from 1. Consonant --> 2. Vowel.
For 세 we read from 1. Consonant --> 2. Vowel.
For 요 we read from 1. Consonant --> 2. Vowel. ㅇ is in 1. position, so there's no sound for ㅇ.

Let's train more.

 ㄱ (g)

 ㄱ (g) + ㅏ (a) = 가 (ga) = go
ㅋ (k) and ㅍ (p)

 ㅋ (k) + ㅓ (eo) = 커 (keo)

 ㅍ (p) + ㅣ (i) = 피 (pi)

 커피 (keo-pi) = coffee
ㅋ (k)

 ㅋ (k) + ㅓ (eo) = 커 (keo)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 커요 (keo-yo) = big
ㅇ (no sound / ng)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅖ (ye) = 예 (ye)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 예요 (ye-yo)
ㅊ (ch)

 ㅊ (ch) + ㅜ (u) = 추 [chu]

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅝ (wo) = 워 (wo)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 추워요 (chu-wo-yo) = cold
ㅈ (j) and ㄴ (n)

 ㅈ (j) + ㅓ (eo) = 저 (jeo)

 ㄴ (n) + ㅡ (eu) + ㄴ (n) = 는 (neun)

 저는 (jeo-neun) = me
ㅃ (pp)

 ㅃ (pp) + ㅏ (a) + ㅇ (ng)= 빵 (ppang)

 빵 (ppang) = bread
ㄴ (n)

 ㄴ (n) + ㅐ (ae) = 내 [nae]

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅣ (i) + ㄹ (r/l) = 일 (il)

 내일 (nae-il) = tomorrow
ㅅ (s) and ㅂ (b)

 ㅅ (s) + ㅜ (u) = 수 [su]

 ㅂ (b) + ㅏ (a) + ㄱ (g) = 박 (su-bag)

 수박 (su-bag) = watermelon
ㄷ (d)

 ㄷ (d) + ㅓ (eo) = 더 [deo]

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅝ (wo) = 워 (wo)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 더워요 (deo-wo-yo) = hot
ㅃ (pp)

 ㅃ (pp) + ㅏ (a) + ㄹ (r/l)= 빨 (ppal)

 ㄹ (r/l) + ㅏ (a) = 라 (la)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 빨라요 (ppal-la-yo) = fast
ㅁ (m)

 ㅁ (m) + ㅓ (eo) + ㄱ (g) = 먹 (meog)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅓ (eo) = 어 (eo)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 먹어요 (meo-geo-yo) = eat
ㅎ (h)

 ㅎ (h) + ㅐ (ae) = 해 (hae)

 ㅇ (no sound) + ㅛ (yo) = 요 (yo)

 해요 (hae-yo) = doing
